question: How must an insurer align the establishment of its risk monitoring metrics with the obligation to maintain and monitor a liquidity buffer so that liabilities can be met as they fall due under both benign and stressed conditions?
gold_answer: An insurer must design and use its risk monitoring metrics in a way that directly supports how it determines, maintains, and evidences any liquidity buffer(s) it holds, because those metrics are part of the framework used to size and track liquid resources against expected outflows [#SRC:9c279e6bff2a8352]. In parallel, the insurer is required to invest in assets that ensure the liquidity of its investment portfolio and to consider whether its assets are appropriate to meet obligations as they fall due, which includes considering total liquidity needs and the level and monitoring of liquid assets [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0]. Practically, this means the insurer’s metrics should be capable of monitoring liquid assets and informing decisions about an appropriate liquidity buffer, including under stressed conditions, so the insurer can demonstrate it maintains an adequate stock of liquid assets sufficient to meet liabilities as they fall due [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0]. The linkage is that the metrics are not standalone reporting; they are used to support the establishment and ongoing adequacy of the liquidity buffer(s) held by the insurer [#SRC:9c279e6bff2a8352].
source_text: used to support the establishment of the insurer’s risk monitoring metrics and any liquidity buffer(s) held by the insurer (set out in more detail in Chapter 5 );
target_text: Under Investments 2.1 , a UK Solvency II firm, the Society and managing agents are required to invest in assets that ensure the liquidity of their investment portfolio and, under Conditions Governing Business 3.1A(4)(b) , to consider the appropriateness of their assets in order to meet obligations as they fall due. Under paragraphs 1.63(b) and (c) of EIOPA Guideline 26 an insurer should consider its total liquidity needs, including an appropriate liquidity buffer and consider the level and monitoring of liquid assets, as well as potential haircuts that could be imposed on their sale. A non-Directive insurer, under Insurance Company – Overall Resources and Valuation 2.3 or Friendly Society – Financial Prudence 4.1 must maintain adequate liquidity to ensure there is no significant risk that its liabilities cannot be met as they fall due. An insurer must therefore maintain an adequate stock of liquid assets, hereafter called a ‘liquidity buffer’, sufficient to meet liabilities as they fall due, and is expected to do so under both benign and stressed conditions.

question: How must a firm ensure that its governance arrangements are not only established for prudent management of its own business, but also applied consistently across all undertakings within the scope of group supervision so that governance and reporting can be controlled at group level?
gold_answer: A firm must first ensure it has an effective system of governance in place that supports sound and prudent management of its business [#TGT:b4d0f4b56df92dd6]. In addition, where there are undertakings included in the scope of group supervision, the firm must ensure that the effective system of governance and the associated reporting procedures are implemented consistently across all those undertakings, rather than applied unevenly or only within the firm itself [#SRC:81456a787f326c75]. This consistent implementation is required so that the governance and reporting procedures can be controlled at the level of the group, meaning the arrangements should be capable of being overseen and managed on a group-wide basis, not merely at individual-entity level [#SRC:81456a787f326c75]. Taken together, the obligations require both (i) establishment of an effective governance system for the firm’s prudent management and (ii) consistent, group-wide implementation of governance and reporting procedures across the supervised group to enable effective group-level control [#TGT:b4d0f4b56df92dd6] [#SRC:81456a787f326c75].
source_text: (2) Without prejudice to (1), the effective system of governance and reporting procedures must be implemented consistently in all the undertakings included in the scope of group supervision under 2.2(1) and 2.2(2) so that the effective system of governance and reporting procedures can be controlled at the level of the group .
target_text: (1) A firm must have in place an effective system of governance which provides for sound and prudent management of its business.

question: If a society isn’t publicly quoted and is setting up or checking its corporate governance arrangements, what code(s) should it look at, and if it uses the Combined Code, which time period does that Combined Code cover?
gold_answer: When a society that is not publicly quoted is putting in place its corporate governance arrangements, or later reviewing them, it should take into account a recognised governance code—either the UK Corporate Governance Code or the Combined Code—whichever is appropriate for its situation. [#SRC:1da93b3de3471f0b] If the society chooses to have regard to the Combined Code, the Combined Code being referred to is the Combined Code on Corporate Governance that was developed by the Corporate Governance Committee of the Financial Reporting Council. [#TGT:a3566db56919a9f0] That referenced Combined Code is also limited by timing: it applies to accounting periods that begin before 29 June 2010. [#TGT:a3566db56919a9f0] So, the society’s decision about which code to consider happens in the context of establishing or reviewing its governance arrangements, and the Combined Code option is specifically the Financial Reporting Council committee’s version with the stated accounting-period start-date boundary. [#SRC:1da93b3de3471f0b] This links the society’s governance-review activity to a clearly identified Combined Code and its defined time scope. [#TGT:a3566db56919a9f0]
source_text: Although societies are not publicly quoted, they should have regard to the UK Corporate Governance Code 4 or the Combined Code 5 as appropriate when they establish and review their corporate governance arrangements.
target_text: 5. The Combined Code on Corporate Governance, developed by the Corporate Governance Committee of the Financial Reporting Council for accounting periods beginning before 29 June 2010.

question: When a firm is reapplying the methodology and calibration of the floor in its modelling of the stressed FS, may it use constructed data if some of the underlying data needed for that exercise is unavailable or unreliable, and what constraints apply to ensure the floor remains appropriately calibrated?
gold_answer: In reapplying the methodology and calibration of the floor as part of modelling the stressed FS, the firm is expected to maintain a floor based on long-term average spreads and, at a minimum, to reapply the methodology and calibration of the floor as previously set out; any changes to the floor are expected to be justified and must not lead to a calibration below what would result from reapplying the methodology and calibration used to calculate the TPs [#SRC:c25a4960dc77cc1d]. If, in performing that reapplication, part of the relevant data is not available or the available data is not reliable, constructed data may be used, but only if it is based on prudent assumptions and is itself grounded in available and reliable data relating to the previous 30 years [#TGT:5f5585242ebb290e]. Read together, this means constructed data is a permitted input to support the reapplication exercise, but it does not relax the expectation to maintain the floor at an appropriate minimum level or the constraint that any resulting calibration cannot be lower than the outcome that would have been obtained by reapplying the established methodology and calibration.
source_text: The PRA expects firms to maintain a floor (ie a minimum level of FS at the appropriate point of the calculation) based on long-term average spreads as part of their modelling of the stressed FS. As a minimum, the PRA expects firms to reapply the methodology and calibration of the floor as set out in Matching Adjustment 4.11 to 4.15 . If any changes are made to the floor, the PRA expects these changes to be justified. They should not result in a calibration below that which would have been obtained by re-applying the methodology and calibration used to calculate the TPs.
target_text: Where part of the data referred to in 4.13(4) is not available or where the available data is not reliable, constructed data based on prudent assumptions may be used; and the constructed data must be based on available and reliable data relating to the previous 30 years.

question: If a bank is growing and expects the Bank might change its preferred resolution strategy, what should the bank do early to get ready for new policies, including operational continuity in resolution, and where in the PRA Rulebook should it look for the operational continuity material?
gold_answer: A growing bank should not wait until a change is imminent. Because, as a bank grows, the Bank can change its preferred resolution strategy to a partial transfer or a bail-in resolution strategy, banks should use forward planning to anticipate when their preferred resolution strategy may change and when they will come into scope of different policies. The passage highlights that banks should be aware of the PRA’s and the Bank’s Resolvability Assessment Framework (RAF) and use that awareness to identify upcoming policy scope changes, including operational continuity in resolution (OCIR). Banks should plan for this well in advance and consider how they will transition to meet these policies, meaning they should prepare a transition approach that aligns their operational arrangements to the OCIR-related expectations that will apply once they are in scope [#SRC:782c0514fa3d2263]. For the specific operational continuity material to support that transition planning, the referenced location is the Operational Continuity Part of the PRA Rulebook [#TGT:bde23c337e322fa8].
source_text: As a bank grows, the Bank can change its preferred resolution strategy to either a partial transfer or a bail-in resolution strategy. Banks should be aware of the PRA’s and the Bank’s Resolvability Assessment Framework (RAF) and, as part of their forward planning, anticipate when their preferred resolution strategy may change and when they will come into scope of different policies, for example the MREL 70 or operational continuity in resolution (OCIR). 71 72 Banks should plan for this well in advance and consider how they will transition to meet these policies.
target_text: 72. Operational Continuity Part of the PRA Rulebook: http://www.prarulebook.co.uk/rulebook/Content/Part/320890 .

question: If someone asks why the PRA will publish reports on the MA framework and what they will include, what should you say, and how do you point them to the exact Solvency II Review reference mentioned in the consultation response?
gold_answer: You should explain that the PRA plans to publish regular reports on the MA framework to improve transparency and to put into effect the outcome of HMT’s Solvency II Review. [#SRC:39a4eb87d14f02a4] You should also say what the reports will cover and when they start: they will be published alongside the PRA Annual Report, they will include application review timelines and decision rates, and the first report is planned for 2025. [#SRC:39a4eb87d14f02a4] To point to the exact Solvency II Review reference, you should direct the reader to paragraph 1.17 of the document titled ‘Review of Solvency II: Consultation - Response’ (available at the government consultation link), because that is the specific place identified for the Solvency II Review reference. [#TGT:e036eff0bbda3fb3] Bringing both points together, the PRA’s stated reporting package (regular MA framework reports with those metrics, starting in 2025) should be presented as the transparency mechanism that supports implementing the outcome of the HMT Solvency II Review that is cross-referenced via paragraph 1.17 in the consultation response. [#SRC:39a4eb87d14f02a4] [#TGT:e036eff0bbda3fb3]
source_text: In order to promote transparency in the regulatory regime, and to implement the outcome of HMT’s Solvency II Review 15 , the PRA will publish regular reports on the MA framework alongside the PRA Annual Report, covering application review timelines and decision rates, with the first report to be published in 2025.
target_text: 15. Paragraph 1.17 of ‘Review of Solvency II: Consultation - Response’: www.gov.uk/government/consultations/solvency-ii-review-consultation .

question: If a firm says it has identified an economic downturn, how far back does it need to look at economic indicators, and what does it need to do if that lookback does not show severe enough downturn values, given the Technical Standards (Economic Downturn) Instrument 2021?
gold_answer: If a firm identifies an economic downturn, it must review economic indicators over a historical time-span that produces values representative of the likely range of future variability, and that time-span must be at least 20 years [#SRC:c5c800b2b7424aab]. The PRA also expects the firm to pick a historical period that allows it to identify indicator values that are sufficiently severe for downturn conditions; the minimum period is not necessarily enough if it does not capture severe conditions [#SRC:c5c800b2b7424aab]. In that case, the firm should extend the historical time-span beyond the 20-year minimum so that the indicator values used reflect sufficiently severe downturn conditions [#SRC:c5c800b2b7424aab]. The Technical Standards (Economic Downturn) Instrument 2021 implements the relevant Technical Standards, so the firm should apply these requirements and expectations as they are implemented through that Instrument, rather than treating them as optional guidance [#TGT:d2850b5b59c0e5dd].
source_text: As required by the UK Technical Standards on the specification of the nature, severity and duration of an economic downturn 8 , firms that identify an economic downturn must examine economic indicators over a historical time-span that provides values that are representative of the likely range of variability in the future, and that this period must have a duration of at least 20 years. The PRA expects that firms should select a historical time-span which enables the identification of economic indicator values that represent sufficiently severe downturn conditions. If the values do not represent sufficiently severe downturn conditions, firms should extend their historical time-span beyond the minimum 20 year period.
target_text: 8. As implemented by the Technical Standards (Economic Downturn) Instrument 2021.

question: Where a group is within the scenario in which the relevant provisions apply at the level of an insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company that is not UK/Gibraltar‑headquartered, or at the level of a third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking, how must a relevant insurance group undertaking characterise the parent undertaking for group solvency calculation purposes, and how does that characterisation interact with the scope of requirements applied at that level?
gold_answer: When the group is one to which the relevant trigger applies, the framework extends specified requirements to operate “at the level of” an insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company that does not have its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, or at the level of a third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking, subject to stated exceptions in that scope statement [#TGT:4b76a4f92f32f4d8]. In that same situation, for the specific task of calculating the solvency of the group, a relevant insurance group undertaking has a distinct obligation regarding how it must treat the parent undertaking: it must treat the parent undertaking—where the parent undertaking is an insurance holding company without a UK/Gibraltar head office, or a third country insurance undertaking, or a third country reinsurance undertaking—solely for the purposes of that solvency calculation as a UK Solvency II firm to which the referenced application condition applies [#SRC:9faaabced2ba31fb]. The interaction is therefore purpose- and level-specific: the scope provision determines that the listed requirements apply with necessary changes at the parent-level entity, while the calculation obligation requires a UK Solvency II firm treatment only for the solvency calculation, without asserting that re-characterisation for all other purposes.
source_text: When calculating the solvency of a group falling within 2.1(3) for the purpose of 20.1 , a relevant insurance group undertaking must treat the parent undertaking (being an insurance holding company which does not have its head office in the UK or Gibraltar or a third country insurance undertaking or a third country reinsurance undertaking ), solely for the purposes of that calculation, as a UK Solvency II firm to which 2.1(1)(a) applies.
target_text: When 2.1(3) applies, 4 to 14 , 16 to 19 and External Audit 2 to 4 apply with any necessary changes at the level of the insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company which does not have its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking unless:

question: For a firm using an internal model, what must be included in template AoC.01 and how must it be submitted to the PRA, taking into account both the PRA’s description of AoC.01 and the annual submission requirement and instructions referenced for internal models?
gold_answer: A firm using an internal model is required to provide the PRA with template AoC.01 on an annual basis, and that submission must follow the specific instructions identified for AoC.01. [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] AoC.01 is the PRA’s analysis of change template that firms complete with key information about movements in the SCR, and it is to be submitted in line with the relevant provisions cited for submission in the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook. [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291] In terms of content, the annual AoC.01 submission must set out the analysis of change referenced in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A and include both quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis. [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] Operationally, the firm should (i) complete AoC.01 with the key information regarding movement in SCR, (ii) ensure the template includes the quantitative elements and the accompanying qualitative analysis required for internal model reporting, and (iii) submit it to the PRA annually using the instructions in section AoC.01 of Chapter 10. [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291] [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] The submission should also be made in accordance with Articles 19 and 35 of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook, as referenced for AoC.01. [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291]
source_text: The PRA has provided an analysis of change template, named AoC.01, for firms to complete with key information regarding the movement in SCR and submit in accordance with Articles 19 and 35 of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: Firms using an internal model must submit to the PRA annually template AoC.01 setting out the analysis of change referred to in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A , including both quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis, in accordance with the instructions set out in section AoC.01 of Chapter 10 .

question: When documenting changes to the terms and conditions of CCDS, PPDS, PIBS 26 and share and deposit accounts—particularly where the change involves integrating the product lines of the transferor society(ies) into those of the transferee or successor society—how should PIBS 26 be characterised based on the definition provided?
gold_answer: PIBS 26 should be treated as a specific instrument whose nature is defined as “Permanent interest-bearing shares,” and it is further characterised as a type of deferred share; that characterisation should be used when describing or assessing changes to the terms and conditions that apply to PIBS 26 within the broader set of products listed. [#TGT:91aeec4ad31299e3] The relevant change scenario includes any amendments to the terms and conditions of CCDS, PPDS, PIBS 26, and share and deposit accounts, and it expressly encompasses changes arising from integrating the product lines of the transferor society(ies) into those of the transferee or successor society. [#SRC:3bbbda00879e9203] Accordingly, when the integration of product lines results in revised terms for PIBS 26, the documentation should reflect that the affected product is a permanent interest-bearing share (i.e., a deferred share type), rather than treating it as an undefined or generic account product. [#TGT:91aeec4ad31299e3] This ensures the change description aligns the product-specific definition of PIBS 26 with the scope of term-and-condition changes contemplated for integration between the transferor society(ies) and the transferee or successor society. [#SRC:3bbbda00879e9203]
source_text: (a) any changes to the terms and conditions of CCDS, PPDS, PIBS 26 and share and deposit accounts, including the integration of the product lines of the transferor society(ies) into those of the transferee or successor society;
target_text: 26. Permanent interest-bearing shares, a type of deferred share.

question: If a firm looks at the effect of the VA as part of its asset-liability management (under Conditions Governing Business 3.2 and 3.3), what does it have to send in its annual report, and what extra write-up is needed if setting the matching adjustment or the volatility adjustment to zero would make it fail the SCR?
gold_answer: When the firm’s work includes assessing the effect of the VA as part of its asset-liability management under Conditions Governing Business 3.2 and 3.3, that VA-focused assessment sits within the set of assessments tied to 3.2 for reporting purposes. [#SRC:4b628eed64a26759] The firm must submit the assessments referred to in 3.2 as part of the information it reports annually in line with Reporting 2. [#TGT:8241a37abe32a389] If, in addition, reducing the matching adjustment or the volatility adjustment to zero would cause the firm to be non-compliant with the SCR, the firm has to provide more than just the assessment itself. [#TGT:8241a37abe32a389] In that case, it must also submit an analysis of the measures it could apply to deal with the shortfall—either by re-establishing the level of eligible own funds covering the SCR or by reducing its risk profile so that SCR compliance is restored. [#TGT:8241a37abe32a389] Practically, the annual package should therefore include the VA effect assessment (as part of asset-liability management) and, where the zero-adjustment scenario would break SCR compliance, a clear analysis of the firm’s potential corrective measures. [#SRC:4b628eed64a26759] [#TGT:8241a37abe32a389]
source_text: (c) the assessment of the effect of the VA as a part of the firm’s asset-liability management ( Conditions Governing Business 3.2 and 3.3 ).
target_text: A firm must submit the assessments referred to in 3.2 as part of the information reported annually in accordance with Reporting 2 . Where the reduction of the matching adjustment or the volatility adjustment to zero would result in non-compliance with the SCR , the firm must also submit an analysis of the measures it could apply in such a situation to re-establish the level of the e ligible own funds covering the SCR or to reduce its risk profile to restore compliance with the SCR .

question: For which firms does the PRA requirement to maintain a recovery plan with a range of executable options apply, and how does that requirement extend to the TWD option given it is treated as a recovery option under SS9/17?
gold_answer: The obligation to maintain a recovery plan containing a range of executable options applies to all firms that are subject to the PRA’s recovery planning rules [#SRC:79cc8d3f5662f4d8]. Where a firm is considering the TWD option, the scope of applicable expectations is clarified by the fact that the TWD option is identified as a recovery option, meaning the expectations in SS9/17 apply to it [#TGT:cdec50384b35267e]. In practice, this links the baseline requirement for covered firms to have a recovery plan with executable options to the specific treatment of TWD within that recovery planning framework: if the firm is within scope of the PRA recovery planning rules, and it uses or includes TWD as a recovery option, it should treat TWD as subject to SS9/17 expectations. Those expectations are described as covering areas such as governance, information and reporting requirements, and the use of fire drills and playbooks, among other areas [#SRC:79cc8d3f5662f4d8], and the interaction with other relevant PRA policies and the SS is set out in the PRA’s Trading activity wind-down SoP [#TGT:cdec50384b35267e].
source_text: All firms subject to the PRA’s recovery planning rules are required to have a recovery plan containing a range of executable options. SS9/17 sets out expectations for recovery planning relating to governance, information and reporting requirements, fire drills and playbooks, amongst other areas. 7
target_text: 7. As the TWD option is a recovery option, the expectations in SS9/17 apply. The interaction between the expectations in SS9/17, other relevant PRA policies, and this SS is set out in the PRA’s Trading activity wind-down SoP.

question: When meeting the expectations for its indicator approach, how must a firm satisfy the obligation to monitor indicators for a solvent exit while relying on, and tailoring, its existing management information and recovery-planning indicator frameworks rather than creating a separate new set?
gold_answer: A firm is permitted to meet the relevant expectations by drawing on and adapting its existing management information framework and any indicator framework developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations, without necessarily creating and monitoring a wholly new set of indicators [#SRC:123f8b7afeb33b32]. However, that flexibility does not remove the firm’s monitoring obligation: the firm should monitor both the projected and actual levels of the indicators it uses, and also monitor their trend over time [#TGT:30201d932e512926]. In practice, the firm should ensure that whichever indicators it selects from, or builds upon within, its existing frameworks are tracked in a way that captures forward-looking projections and realised outcomes, and that trend information is maintained so changes can be identified promptly [#TGT:30201d932e512926]. The monitored indicators, together with other relevant information, should be used to support clear and timely decision-making regarding a solvent exit, meaning the firm should be able to use the adapted framework to inform decisions without delay or ambiguity [#TGT:30201d932e512926], while still leveraging existing structures as permitted [#SRC:123f8b7afeb33b32].
source_text: To meet the expectations in paragraphs 2.7 and 2.8 , a firm may draw on and adapt its existing management information framework, and indicator framework developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations, 24 without necessarily creating and monitoring a new set of indicators.
target_text: A firm should monitor the projected and actual levels of these indicators, as well as their trend. These indicators, alongside other relevant information, 23 should support clear and timely decision-making regarding a solvent exit.

question: If a firm has already done end-to-end mapping of its important business services under Chapter 4, how can it use that work to help write down what it needs (people, processes, technology, facilities and information) to deliver each important business service, including intragroup and other dependencies?
gold_answer: The firm can use its Chapter 4 end-to-end mapping as a practical foundation for the documentation it must produce for each important business service. [#SRC:47c57621ff7696dd] The required documentation must identify the necessary people, processes, technology, facilities and information needed to deliver each important business service, so the firm should structure its write-up to capture those items for every service. [#TGT:b33e7a291295fbdf] It may then extend or align that same mapping output to document and map intragroup and other dependencies, so that dependencies are recorded alongside (and connected to) the people, processes, technology, facilities and information that enable delivery. [#SRC:47c57621ff7696dd] [#TGT:b33e7a291295fbdf] Put another way, the firm should treat the end-to-end mapping under Chapter 4 as the mechanism to connect “what is necessary to deliver the service” with “which intragroup and other dependencies support those necessary elements,” ensuring both are documented for each important business service. [#TGT:b33e7a291295fbdf] [#SRC:47c57621ff7696dd]
source_text: Firms may also leverage their end-to-end mapping of important business services under Chapter 4 of the Operational Resilience – CRR Firms and Operational Resilience – Solvency II Parts of the PRA Rulebook to document and map their intragroup and other dependencies.
target_text: As part of its obligation under 3.1 , a firm must identify and document the necessary people, processes, technology, facilities and information required to deliver each of its important business services .

question: If an institution that acts as a clearing member is working out its CVA own-funds requirement under Title VI using the reduced exposure at default from paragraphs 3–5, and it also uses the Section 5 method for its exposures to a client, what maturity factor can it use for that client calculation?
gold_answer: In that situation, the institution that acts as a clearing member can use a maturity factor of 0.21 when it applies the Section 5 method to calculate the own funds requirement for its exposures to a client. [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e] This sits alongside (and does not replace) the separate permission for a clearing member to use a reduced exposure at default—specifically, the reduced exposure at default that results from the calculations in paragraphs 3, 4 and 5—when calculating its own funds requirements for CVA risk under Title VI. [#SRC:e0f6e3ca4abbfbea] So, the combined approach is: use the reduced exposure at default from paragraphs 3–5 for the Title VI CVA own-funds calculation, and, when the calculation step concerns exposures to a client under the Section 5 method, apply the 0.21 maturity factor within that Section 5 computation. [#SRC:e0f6e3ca4abbfbea] [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e] The 0.21 maturity factor is explicitly allowed as a derogation from point (d) of Article 282(4) for that Section 5 client-exposure calculation. [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e]
source_text: An institution that acts as a clearing member may use the reduced exposure at default resulting from the calculations set out in paragraphs 3 , 4 and 5 for the purposes of calculating its own funds requirements for CVA risk in accordance with Title VI.
target_text: By way of derogation from point (d) of Article 282(4) , where an institution that acts as a clearing member uses the method set out in Section 5 to calculate the own funds requirement for its exposures to a client , that institution may use a maturity factor of 0.21 in that calculation.

question: If a society is preparing for a meeting with Transfer Resolutions, what should its systems do to work out who can vote and help scrutineers check votes, especially where someone is a member but is under 18?
gold_answer: The society’s systems should be set up to identify which members are eligible to vote and to support both sending meeting notices to the right people and enabling scrutineers to validate votes on the Transfer Resolutions. [#SRC:9fd911ad237f25a8] To do that, the systems must be able to recognise eligible members by combining share account balances for multiple account holders to test whether they meet the required qualifying shareholding, checking continuity of shareholding, and identifying minors. [#SRC:9fd911ad237f25a8] These operational checks must be applied within the statutory membership categories: a person can only be a member if they are a shareholding member (holding a share, including an investment in a share account, CCDS, PPDS or PIBS) or a borrowing member (indebted on a loan fully secured on land, with the Rules potentially adjusting when borrowing membership is conferred or ends). [#TGT:fc30977c5a30e80e] Because a minor may be a member but cannot vote on any resolution, the system’s “eligible to vote” output should exclude minors even if they otherwise appear as members, so scrutineers can reject any votes cast by them. [#TGT:fc30977c5a30e80e] This combined approach ensures notices go to those entitled to receive them and that vote validation is properly supported. [#SRC:9fd911ad237f25a8]
source_text: A society’s systems must also be capable of recognising those members who are eligible to vote by, for example, aggregating share account balances of multiple account holders to check that they have the requisite qualifying shareholding, by checking members’ continuity of shareholding, and by identifying minors (see paragraphs 3.108 , 3.109 and 3.110 ). This information is required to ensure that the notice of the meeting is sent to all the members entitled to receive it, and that the scrutineers have adequate systems to validate the votes cast on the Transfer Resolutions.
target_text: Paragraph 5 of Schedule 2 to the 1986 Act provides that no person may be a member of a building society unless he or she is a shareholding member or a borrowing member. A shareholding member is a person who holds a share in the society (that is, an investment in a share account, CCDS, PPDS or PIBS). A borrowing member is a person who is indebted to the society in respect of a loan fully secured on land. However, the Rules may provide that borrowing membership is conferred by a loan substantially secured on land, or shall cease if the loan is foreclosed or the land is taken into possession by the society. A minor (that is a person under 18 years of age) may be a member, but may not vote on any resolution.

question: When maintaining a model inventory that must document a model’s operating boundaries, how should the firm describe those boundaries and the risk implication of using the model outside them, given the definition of operating boundaries as a sample data range (including multivariate variance-covariance relationships)?
gold_answer: The model inventory should record each model’s operating boundaries as part of documenting the model’s purpose and use, and it should do so in a way that reflects that operating boundaries are the conditions under which model performance is expected to be acceptable. [#SRC:7e96d775d78d33bd] In describing those operating boundaries, the firm should characterize them as the sample data range used to estimate the parameters of the statistical model, including (where relevant) the empirical variance-covariance relationships in multivariate settings. [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b] The inventory entry should also link the boundary description to the model’s intended versus actual use by indicating whether the model is being applied within that sample data range or is being extrapolated beyond it. [#SRC:7e96d775d78d33bd] Where the model is used beyond its operating boundaries—such as in shock or stressed economic conditions reflected by macroeconomic indices—the inventory should flag that this extrapolation should be assumed to involve increased model risk. [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b] This boundary-and-risk articulation should sit alongside the other required inventory elements (assumptions/limitations, validation findings, and governance details) so that boundary exceedances can be understood in context and tracked for remediation where applicable. [#SRC:7e96d775d78d33bd]
source_text: c) The types of information the model inventory should capture include: (i) the purpose and use of a model. For example, the relevant product or portfolio, the intended use of the model with a comparison to its actual use, and the model operating boundaries 7 under which model performance is expected to be acceptable; (ii) model assumptions and limitations. For example, risks not captured in model and limitations in the data used to calibrate the model; (iii) findings from validation. For example, indicators of whether models are functioning properly, the dates when those indicators were last updated, any outstanding remediation actions; and (iv) governance details. For example, the names of individuals responsible for validation, the dates when validation was last performed, and the frequency of future validation.

Operating boundaries is defined here as the sample data range (including empirical variance-covariance relationships in the multivariate case) used to measure of model performance per se, extrapolating beyond a model's ‘operating boundaries’ (such as macroeconomic indices in shock or stressed economic conditions) should be assumed to involve increased model risk. estimate the parameters of a statistical model. While not a measure of model performance per se, extrapolating beyond a model's ‘operating boundaries’ (such as macroeconomic indices in shock or stressed economic conditions) should be assumed to involve increased model risk.

question: If a local entity’s risk is reduced by group-level risk management or internal controls, can that count as being mitigated “by other means” instead of through the risk based capital framework, and what should the Applicant check to support that view?
gold_answer: Yes. The Applicant can treat group-level risk management processes or internal control mechanisms as a form of mitigation “by other means,” provided they actually reduce the risk faced by the local entity and therefore support the conclusion that the risk is already mitigated [#TGT:7a8270fc93e6d439]. This fits alongside the alternative route where risks are already mitigated through the risk based capital framework [#SRC:38e88c1cbf288dce]. To support this view, the Applicant should check and record which risks are being addressed, whether the mitigation is achieved through the capital framework or through other means, and—where relying on group-level arrangements—how those group-level processes or controls operate in practice to mitigate the local entity’s risk. The Applicant should also ensure the explanation clearly links the group-level mechanisms to the specific local risk being mitigated, so it is evident why the risk can be treated as already mitigated either through the capital framework or through the group-level “other means.”
source_text: (i) are already mitigated through the risk based capital framework 20 or by other means; 21 or
target_text: 21. For example, the risk of a local entity might be mitigated at the group level through risk management processes or internal control mechanisms established at the group level.

question: When an Institution is preparing the disclosures that fall within the specified set of points concerning credit risk of the CRR, what must it disclose about its risk management objectives and policies, and how must it align those disclosures with the applicable table and instructions?
gold_answer: Where the disclosure being prepared is one of the specified disclosures concerning credit risk of the CRR, the Institution must treat that as within the scoped set of items that are to be made in accordance with the Table UK CRA of Annex XV and the relevant instructions set out in Annex XVI [#SRC:ca610bab35052fa2]. For those disclosures, Institutions shall disclose their risk management objectives and policies for each separate category of risk, and this includes the risks referred to in this Title [#TGT:dedbe720c755ba15]. In practice, this means the Institution should ensure that, for the credit risk disclosures captured by the scope, it provides risk-management objectives and policy information that is organised by separate risk category and is not limited only to a generic statement. The content and presentation of that information must be prepared in a way that is consistent with the referenced table and the accompanying instructions, so that the required risk-management objectives and policies are disclosed in the format and manner contemplated for those credit risk disclosures [#SRC:ca610bab35052fa2] and meet the obligation to disclose objectives and policies by risk category [#TGT:dedbe720c755ba15].

question: If someone has two different life events that create temporary high balances at the same authorised entity, how do you apply the THB limit for each event, and what changes if one of the balances comes from a payment linked to personal injury or incapacity?
gold_answer: You should treat THB protection as applying to each depositor on a per-event, per-authorised-entity basis, so separate life events can be claimed separately rather than being merged into one combined cap. [#SRC:9452d37938f9afef] This approach is intended to apply to natural persons (individuals), and where a trust is involved the relevant person is the underlying beneficiary who must be an individual (with trustees able to claim for the trust as a whole where beneficiaries have less than an absolute beneficial interest, including discretionary trusts). [#SRC:9452d37938f9afef] For the amount payable, the maximum compensation sum for a THB is £1,400,000. [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87] However, if a THB arises from a payment in connection with personal injury or incapacity, there is no maximum limit for that THB compensation. [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87] Putting these together, if a depositor has two qualifying life events, you would assess compensation for each event separately, applying the £1,400,000 maximum to each event unless one event is personal-injury/incapacity-related, in which case that event is not capped. [#SRC:9452d37938f9afef] [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87]
source_text: The PRA considers that the THB protection limit in Depositor Protection 4.3 applies to each depositor on a ‘per event per authorised entity’ basis and is intended to apply to natural persons only (ie individuals) and not all eligible depositors (eg not companies). Where the depositor is a trust, the PRA considers that it is the underlying beneficiary that is required to be an individual. This includes a beneficiary who is absolutely entitled to the deposit (under a bare trust). Trustees of a trust where individual beneficiaries have less than an absolute beneficial interest may make a THB claim on behalf of the trust as a whole. This includes where the trust involves the exercise of discretion (under a discretionary trust). If an individual or a trustee has eligible deposits in excess of £85,000 as a result of more than one of the life events set out in Depositor Protection 10.2 , a claim may be made for compensation in respect of both of those events and the limit in Depositor Protection 4.3 would apply separately to each event. For example, if an individual had a deposit of £750,000 from an inheritance and a deposit of £750,000 from a house sale, then they would be able to claim up to £750,000 in each case.
target_text: Subject to 4.4 , the maximum compensation sum payable for a temporary high balance is £1,400,000, save that no limit shall apply to the compensation payable for a temporary high balance arising from a payment in connection with personal injury or incapacity.

question: If a third country branch has someone acting as head of risk, what approval do they need, and which PRA Supervisory Statement (with date and link) is pointed to for the explanation?
gold_answer: If a third country branch has an individual performing the head of risk role, that person needs to be pre-approved as the Head of Risk function (SMF4). The source also indicates this can cover people doing the head of risk role across multiple UK legal entities, such as a regional CRO responsible for the firm’s UK subsidiaries as well as the branch, so the pre-approval expectation is not limited to a single entity when the role spans the group’s UK footprint [#SRC:b3f688a3830f743b]. The source says this is explained in PRA Supervisory Statement 28/15, “Strengthening individual accountability in banking.” The target provides the publication details needed to find it: PRA Supervisory Statement 28/15, dated July 2015, and the specific Bank of England/PRA webpage URL where it is referenced [#TGT:fe2f4b4552a1cd37].
source_text: Where a third country branch has an individual performing the role of head of risk, he or she will need to be pre-approved as the Head of Risk function (SMF4) as explained in SS28/15 Strengthening individual accountability in banking. 11 This can include individuals performing this role across a range of UK legal entities, such as an regional CRO responsible for this area in the firm’s UK subsidiaries as well as the branch. The PRA expects that an SMF4 should:
target_text: 11. PRA Supervisory Statement 28/15 ‘Strengthening individual accountability in banking’, July 2015, www.bankofengland.co.uk/pra/Pages/publications/ss/2016/ss2815update.aspx .

question: Where an institution is permitted to calculate the exposure value of its derivative positions using the method available only if its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business stays within specified thresholds based on a monthly assessment, what must the institution do if a triggering event occurs that requires it to stop using the relevant exposure-value calculation approach, and by when?
gold_answer: An institution may calculate the exposure value of its derivative positions using the specified method only subject to a stated restriction and only where, based on a monthly assessment using data as of the last day of the month, the size of its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business is at or below the applicable thresholds [#SRC:76ff5419b175628d]. However, that permission is not open-ended: if one of the specified triggering events occurs, the institution has a mandatory transition requirement. In that case, the institution shall cease calculating the exposure values of its derivative positions in accordance with the relevant approach (as applicable) within six months of the triggering event [#TGT:e840f5f94a52b4e7]. Read together, the framework means the institution must both (i) monitor eligibility for the permitted method through the required monthly assessment and (ii) be prepared to discontinue the applicable exposure-value calculation approach within the six-month period once a trigger occurs, even if it previously met the thresholds and could use the method.

question: If a firm wants permission to use an MA, what must it confirm it will do, and what must it not do for the same insurance or reinsurance obligations once it applies the matching adjustment?
gold_answer: A firm applying for permission to use an MA must give a confirmation that it will meet the relevant requirements if permission to apply an MA is granted [#SRC:189b87c3fdc66970]. At the same time, the firm needs to ensure its approach does not conflict with the rule that, where it applies the matching adjustment to a relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations, it must not also apply a risk-free interest rate transitional measure or a volatility adjustment in respect of those obligations [#TGT:9706839fe64ff0b5]. Putting these together, the confirmation should be consistent with how the firm will actually run the MA: it should reflect that the firm’s intended treatment of the relevant portfolio will comply with the prohibition on layering the risk-free interest rate transitional measure or volatility adjustment on top of the matching adjustment for the same obligations. This linkage matters because the firm is committing to meet the applicable requirements if permission is granted [#SRC:189b87c3fdc66970], and one of the key constraints when the matching adjustment is applied is the explicit “must not” restriction for those obligations [#TGT:9706839fe64ff0b5].
source_text: iv. confirmation that the firm will meet the requirements of Matching Adjustment 13.3 if permission to apply an MA is granted;
target_text: A firm that applies the matching adjustment to a relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations must not apply a risk-free interest rate transitional measure or volatility adjustment in respect of those obligations.

question: If a firm uses the TMTP method and has a transfer event that changes the technical provisions covered by TMTP, what does it have to do to update its TMTP methodology, and when should the transferred TMTP be calculated relative to the effective date?
gold_answer: When a firm uses the TMTP method and a ‘transfer event’ causes a change in the firm’s technical provisions to which the TMTP relates, the firm is required to make an update to its TMTP methodology [#SRC:283cc6b77dc06a2b]. For the part of the TMTP that is being transferred, the firm should calculate the ‘transferred TMTP’ immediately prior to the effective date of the transfer or transaction, so the transferred amount is set based on the position just before the transfer becomes effective [#TGT:a7aad619cba8176e]. The firm can only make this update if the business that has been transferred or ceded was already subject to TMTP before the transfer, which limits the update to TMTP-covered business rather than newly in-scope business [#SRC:283cc6b77dc06a2b]. The PRA also expects the update to be based on figures at the effective date of the transfer or transaction, aligning the update process with the transfer timing while still requiring the transferred TMTP calculation to be done immediately before that effective date [#SRC:283cc6b77dc06a2b; #TGT:a7aad619cba8176e].
source_text: Firms that use the TMTP method are required by Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions 6 to make an update to their TMTP methodology following a ‘transfer event’ which has resulted in a change in the firm’s technical provisions to which the TMTP relates. They are also permitted to make revisions to the business designated to the dynamic portion in order to designate acquired business that is MA-eligible in respect of that firm.. Transfer events are: 1) transfer of business either under Part VII of Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (FSMA) or the Friendly Societies Act 1992; 2) the transfer of risk under a 100% reinsurance contract; 3) an amendment to an existing 100% reinsurance contract if there has been a change to the volume of risk to which the reinsurer is exposed; and 4) cancellation, commutation, termination or expiration of an 100% reinsurance contract. Such an update would only be permitted if the business that has been transferred or ceded was subject to TMTP prior to the transfer. The PRA expects this update to be based on figures at the effective date of the transfer or transaction. 5
target_text: 5. The ‘transferred TMTP’ should be as calculated immediately prior to the effective date of the transfer or transaction.

question: For an asset that has both economic cash flow variability risks and event risk exposures, what standard approach should a firm apply, and what cash-flow/yield assumption and FS addition elements must be reflected when the dominant risk is economic?
gold_answer: A firm should apply the standard approach that corresponds to the dominant risk when an asset has both economic and event risk exposures; if economic risk is dominant, the economic-risk standard approach is the relevant one. [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855] Under that economic-risk standard approach, the PRA expects the assumed cash-flow pattern to be based on the investor receiving at least the minimum yield outcome (ie a “yield to worst” assumption). [#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e] If the asset’s features or contractual terms make a different method more appropriate, the firm may use an alternative on a case-by-case basis, but only if the method still assumes the issuer behaves in an economically rational manner. [#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e] In addition, the FS addition within this approach should incorporate an appropriate de minimis allowance for reinvestment risk and rebalancing costs. [#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e] This linkage matters because the dominant-risk selection determines which standard approach framework applies, while the economic-risk framework specifies the yield-to-worst cash-flow assumption and the required de minimis allowance in the FS addition. [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855][#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e]
source_text: The PRA has set out expectations in paragraphs 5.23 to 5.25 below for standard approaches for economic and event risk exposures. For assets with both economic and event risk exposures, firms should follow the approach for the dominant risks. For pooled asset exposures where the underlying assets are exposed to economic risks but where there is sufficient evidence of predictability, firms may propose to apply the standard approach to the FS addition for event risks.
target_text: Where assets are exposed to economic cash flow variability risks, the PRA expects that a standard approach would assume a pattern of cash flows where the yield for the investor is at a minimum (ie ‘yield to worst’). Where the features or contractual terms of an asset make an alternative method more appropriate, this could be considered on a case-by-case basis, provided that the method retains the assumption that the issuer will act in economically rational manner. The FS addition should include an appropriate de minimis allowance for the risk of reinvestment and rebalancing costs as set out in paragraph 5.20 above.

question: Where does the PRA set out the references it considers particularly relevant for the TWD context, and what is the stated purpose and scope of that appendix for helping TWD firms understand how the PRA Rulebook and SSs operate alongside SS1/22?
gold_answer: The PRA indicates that the references it considers particularly relevant in the TWD context are set out in Appendix 1 [#SRC:0556e0f81b3126ee]. In the same appendix, the PRA explains that it has compiled key sections from the PRA Rulebook and SSs that it considers particularly relevant to TWD firms’ understanding of how the relevant rules and expectations work alongside SS1/22 [#TGT:9754592515c621cf]. The PRA further clarifies the intended use and limits of this material: the appendix is not exhaustive, and it is designed to help TWD firms identify the key areas of the PRA’s policy framework in the context of SS1/22 [#TGT:9754592515c621cf]. Read together, these statements mean Appendix 1 functions both as the location where the PRA “sets out” the relevant references for the TWD context and as a curated, non-exhaustive compilation aimed at supporting TWD firms’ navigation of the PRA Rulebook and supervisory statements in relation to SS1/22 [#SRC:0556e0f81b3126ee] [#TGT:9754592515c621cf].
source_text: References that the PRA considers to be particularly relevant in the TWD context have been set out in Appendix 1 .
target_text: In this appendix, the PRA has compiled some of the key sections from the PRA Rulebook and SSs that the PRA considers are particularly relevant for TWD firms’ understanding of how these rules and expectations work alongside SS1/22 . This appendix is not exhaustive, and is designed to help TWD firms identify the key areas of the PRA’s policy framework in the context of SS1/22 .

question: If a firm gets staff from an intragroup service company and treats that as outsourcing, what written contract is expected for critical or important operational functions or activities, and does outsourcing change who is responsible for meeting PRA rules and FSMA-related obligations for UK Solvency II firms?
gold_answer: Where staff provision through an intragroup service company is treated as outsourcing, the firm should pay close attention to that relationship and, if the arrangement involves outsourcing critical or important operational functions or activities, the firm should put in place a written agreement with the service provider that clearly defines the rights and obligations of both parties. [#SRC:699d49de3bdbcc6a] However, outsourcing does not shift the firm’s accountability: if the firm outsources a function or any insurance or reinsurance activity, it still remains fully responsible for discharging all of its obligations under the PRA rules, FSMA, and other laws, rules, regulations, and administrative provisions deriving from FSMA that apply to UK Solvency II firms. [#TGT:c0c1ed2e69073245] The practical linkage is that the contract can allocate tasks and clarify expectations with the intragroup service company, but it cannot be relied on to reduce the firm’s own regulatory responsibilities. [#SRC:699d49de3bdbcc6a][#TGT:c0c1ed2e69073245] Separately, the firm should also consider whether entering into this kind of written agreement creates a need under IAS 19 to recognise the pension scheme on the authorised firm’s balance sheet. [#SRC:699d49de3bdbcc6a]
source_text: Firms should also pay particular attention to relationships with intragroup service companies, where provision of staff can be regarded as having been outsourced to the service company for the purposes of Conditions Governing Business 7 . The Conditions Governing Business Part of the PRA Rulebook requires that, where a firm outsources critical or important operational functions or activities, a written agreement should be entered into between the firm and the service provider which clearly defines the respective rights and obligations of each party. 5 Firms should consider whether a written agreement of this nature leads to a requirement under IAS 19 to recognise the pension scheme on the balance sheet of the authorised firm.
target_text: If a firm outsources a function or any insurance or reinsurance activity, it remains fully responsible for discharging all of its obligations under the PRA rules, FSMA and any other laws, rules, regulations and administrative provisions deriving from FSMA that apply to UK Solvency II firms .

question: When setting a rate of interest for the purposes of 11.1, how do the limits based on (i) the adjusted overall yield on assets and (ii) the assumed yield on an individual asset attributed to the long-term insurance business (including the 2.5% reduction) interact, and what practical cap should be applied to ensure compliance across both the portfolio and asset levels?
gold_answer: To comply when determining a rate of interest for the purposes of 11.1, the rate must be constrained by both a portfolio-level ceiling and an asset-level ceiling, so the practical cap is the most restrictive outcome produced by applying both limits. [#SRC:3a577ffac5cf0ceb] At the portfolio level, the rate of interest determined for 11.1 is not permitted to be higher than the adjusted overall yield on assets, where that adjusted overall yield is computed as a weighted average of the reduced yields on the individual assets (with those reduced yields being the figures arrived at under 11.2). [#SRC:3a577ffac5cf0ceb] In parallel, for each asset attributed to the long-term insurance business, the assumed yield used for 11.1 (before any tax-effect adjustment) must not be higher than the yield on that asset calculated under 11.3 to 11.13, after reducing that calculated yield by 2.5% of itself. [#TGT:82f678b5a7efdda8] Practically, this means you should (i) ensure each asset’s assumed yield respects the “11.3–11.13 yield minus 2.5% of that yield” limit, and then (ii) ensure the overall 11.1 rate does not exceed the weighted-average adjusted overall yield derived from the reduced individual-asset yields. [#TGT:82f678b5a7efdda8] [#SRC:3a577ffac5cf0ceb]
source_text: (1) In no case must a rate of interest determined for the purposes of 11.1 exceed the adjusted overall yield on assets calculated as the weighted average of the reduced yields on the individual assets arrived at under 11.2 .
target_text: For the purposes of 11.1 , the assumed yield on an asset attributed to the long-term insurance business , before any adjustment to take account of the effect of taxation, must not exceed the yield on that asset calculated in accordance with 11.3 to 11.13 , reduced by 2.5% of that yield.

question: If an international bank or UK trading bank wants to change its booking arrangements in a big way and that change could affect risk management, what does the PRA expect the firm to do, and how does this relate to being ready for an orderly resolution with minimal disruption to critical services?
gold_answer: For international banks and UK trading banks, the PRA expects the firm to inform the PRA when it plans material changes to its booking arrangements that could impact how its risk management operates. [#SRC:9efcdb7da1784680] This sits within the PRA’s wider expectations that booking arrangements should be organised to meet the threshold condition on prudent conduct of business and to support the General Organisational Requirements connected to risk management and resolvability. [#SRC:9efcdb7da1784680] The connection to Fundamental Rule 8 is that the firm must prepare for resolution so that, if needed, it can be resolved in an orderly manner with minimum disruption of critical services. [#TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0] Because booking arrangements can affect both risk management and resolvability, the firm should view the planned-change notification as part of maintaining readiness to achieve the orderly-resolution outcome required by Fundamental Rule 8. [#SRC:9efcdb7da1784680] [#TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0]
source_text: The PRA has a number of expectations concerning how international banks and UK trading banks should organise their booking arrangements in order to meet the threshold condition on the prudent conduct of business, their obligations under Fundamental Rules 3 , 5 , 6 and 8 , and under the General Organisational Requirements (GOR) relating to risk management and resolvability. The PRA also has an expectation under Fundamental Rule 7 and General Notification Requirement 2.3(1) that a firm should inform the PRA when it plans to make material changes to its booking arrangements that could impact how its risk management operates.
target_text: Fundamental Rule 8: A firm must prepare for resolution so, if the need arises, it can be resolved in an orderly manner with a minimum disruption of critical services.

question: How should a firm structure its booking governance so that (i) it has a clear booking taxonomy covering remote booking, split desks/shared desks, and branch bookings, and (ii) each individual booking can be traced to a responsible individual while maintaining segregation between trade entry and independent checking?
gold_answer: A firm should implement booking governance that combines a documented booking taxonomy with clear accountability for who may book and who is responsible for the correctness of each booking. The firm should first identify and classify the booking types it uses and maintain a clear, comprehensive taxonomy that defines key terms such as remote booking (in both legal-entity and geographic senses), split desks, shared desks, and the classification of branch bookings. [#TGT:670172cefe48eb87] In parallel, the firm should define and record who is permitted to book and what constitutes a booking, including whether the trader is solely responsible, and it should articulate any distinctions between traders, sales, and sales traders. [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703] The governance should also cover individuals booking into legal entities and branches, including traders based overseas booking into UK branches, and align those scenarios to the taxonomy’s treatment of remote and branch bookings. [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703] The PRA expects the correctness of any given booking to be traceable to at least one (and preferably only one) responsible individual, usually the trader, which should be reflected in the firm’s booking definitions and controls. [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703] Finally, the firm should ensure trade entry is distinct from independent checking and is performed in line with segregation of duties controls, so that the taxonomy and responsibility model do not blur execution/entry with verification. [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703]
source_text: Booking responsibilities: A firm should define and record who is permitted to book and what constitutes a booking including whether the trader is solely responsible. This should articulate the distinction, if any, between traders, sales and sales traders. This should also cover those individuals booking into legal entities and branches including traders based overseas booking into UK branches. The PRA expects the correctness of any given booking to be traced to at least one, and preferably only one, responsible individual, which will usually be the trader. Trade entry is different from the independent checking of the trade and should be performed in line with the firm’s segregation of duties controls. 37
target_text: Booking taxonomy: A firm should identify and classify the types of booking they employ and develop a clear and comprehensive taxonomy to assist with this. This should clearly define the use of terms such as remote booking (legal entity and geographic sense), split desks, and shared desks. The classification of branch bookings should also be covered. The PRA recognises that firms have already developed their own independent taxonomies to describe booking practices and is not seeking to impose common definitions for booking taxonomies at the current time. However, a set of illustrative examples have been provided in the Annex that the PRA considers to be an approximation of current industry practice and represent how the PRA has used certain terms throughout this statement.

question: When a firm is permitted not to follow certain compliance-related requirements because doing so would be disproportionate given the nature, scale and complexity of its business and the nature and range of the relevant services and activities, what must the firm still ensure so that the compliance function can discharge its responsibilities properly and independently?
gold_answer: A firm may be permitted not to comply with certain requirements where, in view of the nature, scale and complexity of its business and the nature and range of the relevant services and activities, compliance would not be proportionate, provided that the firm’s compliance function is, and continues to be, effective [#SRC:029ad42316e71977]. Even where that permission applies, the firm remains subject to an overarching obligation to ensure that the compliance function is able to discharge its responsibilities properly and independently [#TGT:56dd025c30f9e7e2]. Read together, this means the firm cannot treat the proportionality-based non-compliance as a relaxation of the need for an effective compliance function; rather, it must maintain arrangements that support proper and independent performance of the compliance function’s responsibilities while also ensuring the function remains effective on an ongoing basis. The firm should therefore assess proportionality in light of its business and activities, and only rely on the permission if it can demonstrate continuing effectiveness of the compliance function alongside the required ability for that function to operate properly and independently [#SRC:029ad42316e71977] [#TGT:56dd025c30f9e7e2].
source_text: (1) A firm need not comply with the requirements in 2.1D(4) or (5) where: (a) in view of the nature, scale and complexity of its business, and the nature and range of the relevant services and activities , compliance with the requirements under 2.1D(4) or (5) is not proportionate; and (b) the firm's compliance function is, and continues to be, effective.

question: If a firm is in a 2.1(3) group, when does it have to make sure the group’s strategies, processes and systems meet Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3, and when are 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 switched off because the parent’s head office is in a designated overseas jurisdiction under the IRPR regulations?
gold_answer: If the firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3), it is within the scope of a rule that requires the firm to ensure the group’s strategies, processes and systems comply with the obligations in Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3 (with the stated carve-out for Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3.1(3), and with 2.1(3) described as being subject to 22.5). [#TGT:df26169200bb5c19] However, for a 2.1(3) group there is also a separate condition that can turn off the application of 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4: those provisions do not apply if the group parent undertaking’s head office is in a third country that is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations for insurance group supervision, and regulation 14(3) applies. [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8] So you need two checks: (1) confirm the firm is in a group covered by 2.1(3) to identify the group-level operational resilience compliance duty, and (2) confirm the overseas-jurisdiction designation and regulation 14(3) condition to decide whether 22.2–22.4 are disapplied for that firm. [#TGT:df26169200bb5c19] [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8]
source_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3) , 22.2 , 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply if, the third country in which the group's parent undertaking has its head office is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations in respect of insurance group supervision and paragraph (3) of regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations applies.
target_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(1) , 2.1(2) or, subject to 22.5 , 2.1(3) , with the exception of Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3.1(3) , the firm must ensure that the strategies, processes and systems at the level of the group of which it is a member comply with the obligations set out in Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3 .

question: If a credit union wants to offer shares in an ISA tax-free wrapper and also plans to issue fixed-rate shares or deposits, what must it do before it starts, and does HMRC approval change its duty to meet statutory requirements?
gold_answer: The credit union is expected to look to the relevant regulations issued by HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) when it wishes to offer shares in an Individual Savings Account (ISA) tax-free wrapper, and it should not assume that HMRC approval changes its underlying legal compliance position [#SRC:39468cc7f2d4556d]. Separately, if it intends to issue fixed-rate shares or deposits, the PRA expects the credit union to comply with the statutory mandatory requirements that must be satisfied before it begins that activity [#TGT:bb34e94b2a68af4b]. Putting both requirements together, the credit union must (1) refer to and follow the HMRC regulations relevant to the ISA wrapper, (2) treat HMRC approval as not providing any exemption from statutory requirements, and (3) ensure it has satisfied the statutory mandatory requirements that apply before starting to issue fixed-rate shares or deposits. In practice, this means the credit union should complete its statutory readiness checks for the fixed-rate activity even if it has already obtained HMRC approval for the ISA-related offering.
source_text: Credit unions that wish to offer shares in an Individual Savings Account (ISA) tax-free wrapper are expected to refer to the relevant regulations issued by HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC). Credit unions should be aware that approval from HMRC does not provide any degree of exemption from compliance with the statutory requirements referred to above in paragraph 5.2 .
target_text: The PRA expects that any credit union that intends to issue fixed-rate shares or deposits complies with the statutory mandatory requirements that must be satisfied before beginning such activity. 2

question: If a G-SII decides to use the option to publish the Article 441 information somewhere different from the standalone document in Article 434(1), what is the normal “one place, electronic” rule for Titles II and III disclosures, and what can count as that one place?
gold_answer: If a G-SII uses the derogation, it is allowed to put the information required under Article 441 in a separate medium or location rather than in the standalone document referred to in Article 434(1). [#SRC:f339ea4b3db2ad76] Normally, institutions must publish all information required under Titles II and III electronically and in a single medium or location. [#TGT:8422ed9edcda5caa] That single place must be set up in one of two ways: it can be a standalone document that gives users a readily accessible source of prudential information, or it can be a clearly identifiable distinctive section that is included in or appended to the institutions’ financial statements or financial reports and that contains the required disclosures. [#TGT:8422ed9edcda5caa] Putting these together, the G-SII can follow the general approach of having Titles II and III disclosures in one electronic location that meets the required format, while still using the derogation to locate the Article 441 information separately from the Article 434(1) standalone document. [#SRC:f339ea4b3db2ad76] [#TGT:8422ed9edcda5caa]
source_text: By way of derogation from Article 434(1) , where a G-SII relies on the derogation in paragraph 1 , it may disclose the information required under Article 441 in a separate medium or location from the standalone document mentioned in Article 434(1) .
target_text: Institutions shall disclose all the information required under Titles II and III in electronic format and in a single medium or location. The single medium or location shall be a standalone document that provides a readily accessible source of prudential information for users of that information or a distinctive section included in or appended to the institutions' financial statements or financial reports containing the required disclosures and being easily identifiable to those users.

question: For PRA Matching Tests conducted before 31/12/2024, how should a firm treat the past version of Appendix 1 in light of the PRA’s statement that earlier communications described other versions and that the tests set out below are the most recent versions?
gold_answer: For PRA Matching Tests before 31/12/2024, a firm should recognise that the relevant material is framed as a past version of Appendix 1, and therefore reflects an earlier iteration of the PRA Matching Tests for that period [#SRC:64a39e6c30fff620]. At the same time, the PRA has indicated that it has previously communicated other versions of these tests to firms, and that the tests presented “below” are the most recent versions [#TGT:f7e0497cce253472]. Read together, this means a firm should not assume there is only one historical formulation for pre‑31/12/2024 testing; instead, it should treat the past Appendix 1 version as one prior version and be alert to the possibility that other versions may have been described in earlier PRA communications. In practical terms, when documenting which test version was applied for the pre‑31/12/2024 period, the firm should distinguish between the past Appendix 1 version and the most recent versions referenced by the PRA, and ensure its internal records clearly identify which version it relied on for the relevant timeframe [#SRC:64a39e6c30fff620] [#TGT:f7e0497cce253472].
source_text: Past version of Appendix 1 : PRA Matching Tests before 31/12/2024
target_text: In previous communications with firms, the PRA has described other versions of these tests. The tests described below are the most recent versions.

question: If institutions have a derivative transaction with more than one important risk driver, what must they do about mapping it to risk categories, and if it is mapped to the commodity risk category, how must they choose the hedging set?
gold_answer: Institutions must check whether a derivative transaction has more than one material risk driver and then map it accordingly. If all the material risk drivers are in the same risk category, institutions only need to map the transaction once to that category, using the most material risk driver. If the material risk drivers are in different risk categories, institutions must map the transaction once to each risk category where it has at least one material risk driver, and for each such category they must use the most material risk driver in that category [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. In addition, whenever the transaction is mapped to the commodity risk category, institutions must assign it to one of the listed hedging sets. That assignment must be based on the nature of the primary risk driver, or (for the relevant transactions) the most material risk driver within the commodity risk category [#SRC:820ffbb74005c855]. So a single transaction can be mapped multiple times across categories, but its commodity hedging set is chosen by focusing on the primary or most material commodity-related driver.
source_text: (e) transactions mapped to the commodity risk category shall be assigned to one of the following hedging sets on the basis of the nature of their primary risk driver or the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) :
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.

question: When setting remuneration policies, how must smaller firms (Category 3-4 PRA regulated firms) apply proportionality so that they do not treat it as permission to disapply the relevant requirements, while still ensuring the remuneration policy design reflects the firm’s internal organisation and the nature, scale and complexity of the risks inherent in its business?
gold_answer: Smaller firms (Category 3-4 PRA regulated firms) must approach proportionality as a method of tailoring implementation, not as a basis for switching off requirements. The PRA expects these firms to comply appropriately with the relevant Chapter 3A framework when setting remuneration policies, and it is explicit that proportionality does not mean smaller firms can disapply those requirements [#SRC:a1a186c5cfc66eed]. In practice, this means the firm should exercise appropriate judgement to apply the specific arrangements for Solvency II staff proportionately and modify them where required to reflect the size and nature of its business, while still maintaining compliance with the underlying requirements [#SRC:a1a186c5cfc66eed].
