At the same time, the firm must ensure the remuneration policy is designed to take into account its internal organisation and the nature, scale and complexity of the risks inherent in its business [#TGT:07a05eb1c221e73c]. Read together, the obligations require a policy design and implementation approach that is risk- and organisation-sensitive, with proportionate modifications that reflect business characteristics without undermining the continuing applicability of the Chapter 3A requirements.
source_text: The PRA will still expect smaller firms (Category 3-4 PRA regulated firms) to comply appropriately with Chapter 3A when setting their remuneration policies. The application of proportionality under Conditions Governing Business 3A.3 does not equate to smaller firms being able to disapply the Chapter 3A requirements. These firms should be exercising appropriate judgement to ensure that the specific arrangements for Solvency II staff contained in Conditions Governing Business 3A.2 are applied proportionality and modified where required to reflect the size and nature of their businesses.
target_text: A firm must ensure that the remuneration policy is designed in such a way as to take into account the internal organisation of the firm , and the nature, scale and complexity of the risks inherent in its business.

question: If a firm wants to change its model change policy (not just admin edits), does it need PRA permission, and which September 2016 PRA document should it look at for more detail on changes to internal models?
gold_answer: Yes. If a firm changes the model change policy itself and the change is more than administrative, that change is subject to the PRA’s permission, so the firm should treat it as requiring PRA approval rather than as a routine internal update [#SRC:c52cdc2f44519224]. This requirement is linked to the PRA’s broader expectation that firms review the effectiveness of the model change policy on a regular basis to ensure the internal model continues to reflect the firm’s risk profile and continues to meet internal model requirements and calibration standards [#SRC:c52cdc2f44519224]. For additional context on changes to internal models used by UK insurance firms, the referenced publication is SS12/16, which is dated September 2016 and is available via the Bank of England website [#TGT:34ad566f87cce998]. Taken together, the passages indicate that policy governance is part of model governance: regular review is encouraged, but substantive policy changes trigger a permission expectation, and the September 2016 document is the cited reference point.
source_text: The PRA encourages firms to review the effectiveness of the model change policy on a regular basis to ensure that the internal model continues to reflect the firm’s risk profile and meets the internal model requirements and calibration standards. Firms are also reminded that changes to the model change policy itself, other than administrative changes, are subject to the PRA’s permission. Readers also are referred to SS12/16, ‘Changes to internal models used by UK insurance firms’ . 16
target_text: 16. September 2016: http://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2016/solvency2-changes-to-internal-models-used-by-uk-insurance-firms-ss .

question: When calculating risk-weighted exposure amounts for an institution’s trade exposures with CCPs for the purposes of Article 92(3), how must the institution determine the exposure values to be summed, and what framework governs that exposure-value calculation before applying the risk weight?
gold_answer: For the purposes of Article 92(3), an institution must compute the risk-weighted exposure amounts for its trade exposures with CCPs by first determining the exposure values for those trade exposures, then summing those exposure values, and finally multiplying that sum by the applicable risk weight. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40] The exposure values that feed into this sum are not determined ad hoc; they must be calculated in accordance with the specified rule framework, namely Sections 1 to 8 of the relevant Chapter and, where applicable, Section 4 of Chapter 4. [#TGT:325217a9dca51ff6] In addition, the source calculation method requires that the exposure values used in the sum are those calculated in accordance with the internal paragraph-based method referenced for exposure values (paragraphs 2 and 3 of the same Article), before applying the risk weight determined under the referenced paragraph 1. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40] Accordingly, the institution’s process is: calculate exposure values under the prescribed Sections/Chapter framework (and the referenced paragraph method), aggregate those exposure values across its CCP trade exposures, and apply the risk weight to the aggregate to obtain the risk-weighted exposure amount. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40] [#TGT:325217a9dca51ff6]
source_text: An institution shall calculate the risk-weighted exposure amounts for its trade exposures with CCPs for the purposes of Article 92(3) as the sum of the exposure values of its trade exposures with CCPs, calculated in accordance with paragraphs 2 and 3 of this Article, multiplied by the risk weight determined in accordance with paragraph 1 of this Article.
target_text: An institution shall calculate exposure values of its trade exposures with a CCP in accordance with Sections 1 to 8 of this Chapter and with Section 4 of Chapter 4, as applicable.

question: What written statement does a firm need to include in its first MA application to show it meets the MA eligibility conditions, and what is the rule on not using a matching adjustment in best estimate calculations until the firm has a matching adjustment permission?
gold_answer: In its initial MA application, a firm is expected to provide written confirmation that it complies with the MA eligibility conditions, as part of enabling the PRA to be satisfied that the firm meets those conditions before it applies an MA under the IRPR regulations [#SRC:706be7f8963a27d5]. This is important because there is a separate restriction on use: a firm must not apply a matching adjustment to the relevant risk-free interest rate term structure for calculating the best estimate of its insurance or reinsurance obligations unless it has a matching adjustment permission [#TGT:78efaa111a0c4a1d]. Putting these together, the written confirmation is an application requirement aimed at demonstrating compliance with the eligibility conditions to the PRA, but it does not by itself allow the firm to use the matching adjustment in best estimate calculations. The firm should therefore prepare and submit the written confirmation (and, where expected, documentary evidence supporting that confirmation) as part of its initial application, while ensuring it does not apply the matching adjustment in the best estimate calculation unless and until the matching adjustment permission is held [#SRC:706be7f8963a27d5] [#TGT:78efaa111a0c4a1d].
source_text: In order for a firm to apply an MA under the IRPR regulations, the PRA must be satisfied that the firm meets the MA eligibility conditions as set out in regulation 4 of the IRPR regulations and Chapter 2 of the Matching Adjustment Part . As required by Matching Adjustment 3.1 , a firm's initial MA application must contain written confirmation of its compliance with the MA eligibility conditions. For regulation 4(4) of the IRPR regulations and Matching Adjustment 2.2(6) , firms are expected to provide this written confirmation. For other MA eligibility conditions, firms are expected to provide documentary evidence to support their written confirmation, including:
target_text: A firm must not apply a matching adjustment to the relevant risk-free interest rate term structure to calculate the best estimate of its insurance or reinsurance obligations unless it has a matching adjustment permission .

question: When submitting the Merger Document (including the Schedule 16 Statement), what must be included in the Schedule 16 Statement regarding potential conflicts with contractual obligations of either society or their connected undertakings, and how does this requirement apply even where consent to proceed by way of board resolution is being sought in respect of the transferee society?
gold_answer: The Merger Document must include the Schedule 16 Statement, except in the limited circumstance where consent to proceed by way of board resolution is being sought in respect of the transferee society; however, where a Schedule 16 Statement is included as part of the Merger Document, it must contain the specific disclosure the PRA requires about contractual conflicts. In particular, the PRA will require the Schedule 16 Statement to state whether or not the merger will conflict with any contractual obligations of either society or their connected undertakings, and this expressly includes agency agreements. This contractual-conflict disclosure is a required element of the Schedule 16 Statement itself [#TGT:42a09cff8c333fca], and it sits within the broader obligation to provide the Merger Document, including the Schedule 16 Statement, as part of the merger documentation package (subject only to the board-resolution consent scenario for the transferee society) [#SRC:f1c8b930cd8f5ee1]. Accordingly, firms should ensure the Schedule 16 Statement is drafted to cover both societies and their connected undertakings and to address agency agreements alongside other contractual commitments.
source_text: (c) the Merger Document, including the Schedule 16 Statement, unless consent to proceed by way of board resolution is being sought in respect of the transferee society, together with the explanations of change, comparability and commitments referred to in paragraph 3.73 to 3.75 and 3.95 ;
target_text: The PRA will require the Schedule 16 Statement to include a statement as to whether or not the merger will conflict with any contractual obligations, including agency agreements, of either society or their connected undertakings.

question: If a firm updates its model change policy after checking that its internal model still fits its risk profile, when does it need the PRA’s permission, and what is the September 2016 link given for the document it should look at?
gold_answer: A firm is expected to check its model change policy regularly to see whether it is working well, so that the internal model keeps reflecting the firm’s risk profile and continues to meet internal model requirements and calibration standards. [#SRC:c52cdc2f44519224] If the firm then wants to change the model change policy itself, it needs to separate simple administrative edits from other updates, because any change that is not administrative is described as needing the PRA’s permission. [#SRC:c52cdc2f44519224] The text also points the reader to SS12/16, “Changes to internal models used by UK insurance firms,” and the specific reference provided is a September 2016 publication located at http://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2016/solvency2-changes-to-internal-models-used-by-uk-insurance-firms-ss. [#TGT:34ad566f87cce998] So, in a compliant workflow, the firm should (1) perform the regular review for continued fit and standards, (2) classify the intended policy change as administrative or not, and (3) if it is not administrative, treat it as requiring PRA permission while using the cited SS12/16 link as the referenced source for further information. [#SRC:c52cdc2f44519224] [#TGT:34ad566f87cce998]
source_text: The PRA encourages firms to review the effectiveness of the model change policy on a regular basis to ensure that the internal model continues to reflect the firm’s risk profile and meets the internal model requirements and calibration standards. Firms are also reminded that changes to the model change policy itself, other than administrative changes, are subject to the PRA’s permission. Readers also are referred to SS12/16, ‘Changes to internal models used by UK insurance firms’ . 16
target_text: 16. September 2016: http://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2016/solvency2-changes-to-internal-models-used-by-uk-insurance-firms-ss .

question: If a UK subsidiary of a group based outside the UK is working on its recovery plan, when should it contact its supervisor about whether extra UK playbook work applies, and what does it need to do about fire drills before it sends the recovery plan to the PRA?
gold_answer: The UK subsidiary should contact its supervisor during its UK recovery planning work to discuss whether the PRA’s request for more detailed work on UK playbooks applies to it, because the PRA may explicitly ask for that additional playbook work in some cases and the firm is expected to check with its supervisor [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e]. At the same time, the firm needs to plan and perform fire drill exercises as part of testing its recovery plan, because fire drills are ‘live’ simulation exercises used to act out key parts of a response to a designed scenario and test the plan’s effectiveness [#TGT:2c1d7b1bf1be0e5f]. The PRA expects each firm to carry out at least one fire drill on its recovery plan before each submission of the recovery plan to the PRA, with a minimum of one fire drill every three years [#TGT:2c1d7b1bf1be0e5f]. Because the PRA determines submission frequency on a firm-by-firm basis, the firm should time the supervisor discussion so any extra UK playbook work can be reflected in the recovery plan and then exercised in the fire drill(s) that precede the relevant submission [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e] [#TGT:2c1d7b1bf1be0e5f].
source_text: (vii) UK subsidiaries of groups based outside of the UK should also consider the guidance on fire drills and playbooks set out in Chapter 2 (vi) and (vii) . In some cases, the PRA may explicitly ask firms to undertake more detailed work on UK playbooks as part of their UK recovery planning work. Firms should contact their supervisor to discuss whether this applies.
target_text: Fire drill exercises are ‘live’ simulation type exercises where firms act out key parts of a response to a designed scenario. This is a useful way to test the effectiveness of the recovery plan in a ‘live’ situation. The PRA expects each firm to carry out at least one fire drill exercise on its recovery plan prior to each submission of the recovery plan to the PRA, subject to a minimum of one fire drill taking place every three years. The PRA determines the frequency with which firms should submit their recovery plan on a firm-by-firm basis, with larger firms tending to submit their plans on an annual cycle.

question: For a firm that is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3), how should the firm determine whether it must ensure group-level strategies, processes and systems support assessing impact tolerance for important group business services during a severe but plausible disruption, given the condition under which 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply?
gold_answer: A firm that is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3) must ensure that group-level strategies, processes and systems allow the firm to assess whether important group business services could stay within the impact tolerance during a severe but plausible disruption to the firm’s operations. [#SRC:43a647fe4cce5cd9] However, when determining the overall rule set that applies to that same 2.1(3) group context, the firm must also check whether the group’s parent undertaking has its head office in a third country that is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations for insurance group supervision, and whether paragraph (3) of regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations applies. [#TGT:b6b6500b2b9939c8] If those conditions are met, then 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply to the firm in that scenario, even though the firm remains within the population described as a member of a group covered by 2.1(3). [#TGT:b6b6500b2b9939c8] Practically, the firm should (i) confirm it is in scope as a member of a group covered by 2.1(3), and (ii) separately evaluate the third-country/overseas-jurisdiction designation and regulation 14(3) condition to determine whether the 22.2–22.4 provisions are disapplied while still maintaining the group-level capability to assess impact tolerance for important group business services. [#SRC:43a647fe4cce5cd9] [#TGT:b6b6500b2b9939c8]
source_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(1) , 2.1(2) or, subject to 22.5 , 2.1(3) the firm must ensure that the strategies, processes and systems at the level of the group of which it is a member enable the firm to assess whether important group business services at the level of the group could remain within the impact tolerance in the event of a severe but plausible disruption to its operations.
target_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3) , 22.2 , 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply if, the third country in which the group's parent undertaking has its head office is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations in respect of insurance group supervision and paragraph (3) of regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations applies.

question: Before a firm gives an attestation, what analysis and justification must it do about retained risks and earning the matching adjustment, and what must it do with any risks that analysis identifies when it applies the matching adjustment?
gold_answer: Before giving an attestation, a firm must analyse and justify that the fundamental spread it uses reflects compensation for all retained risks, and that the matching adjustment can be earned with a high degree of confidence from the assets held in the relevant portfolio of assets [#TGT:4d06c3de64a9c9ce]. Separately, when the firm applies the matching adjustment, it must manage any risks that are identified in the analysis undertaken for that purpose [#SRC:afd68bad9897c2bc]. Putting these together, the firm’s work before the attestation should be structured to identify the retained risks that matter to the fundamental spread and to support the conclusion about earning the matching adjustment from the relevant portfolio. Then, the firm must not leave those identified risks as theoretical findings: it must actively manage them as part of applying the matching adjustment. In practice, the analysis and justification should be consistent with the assets in the relevant portfolio and should clearly surface the risks that are being retained, because those are the risks the firm must be prepared to manage once it applies the matching adjustment.
source_text: (4) Where a firm applies the matching adjustment , the firm must manage any risks that are identified in the analysis undertaken in accordance with Matching Adjustment 10.1 .
target_text: Before providing any attestation in accordance with 9.1 , a firm must analyse and justify that the fundamental spread used by the firm reflects compensation for all retained risks, and that the matching adjustment can be earned with a high degree of confidence from the assets held in the relevant portfolio of assets .

question: If a firm is using the IFRS 9 transitional arrangements, what does the PRA look at when deciding whether the firm needs a bigger capital buffer, and how does that connect to when IFRS 9 started applying and what older standard it replaced?
gold_answer: Where a firm is using IFRS 9 transitional arrangements, the PRA’s decision on whether the firm should hold a larger buffer or strengthen its capital position is based on a combination of prudential factors and a time-limited transitional assessment. [#SRC:ca2603599644f9a7] The PRA expects firms to increase buffers or strengthen capital where necessary in light of factors including the firm’s leverage ratio, Tier 1 and total capital ratios, risks associated with double leverage, and whether potentially significant risks are not fully captured by the stress test. [#SRC:ca2603599644f9a7] In addition, up to the end of 2023, the PRA will assess firms’ capital positions under transitional arrangements for IFRS 9 when firms are using those arrangements. [#SRC:ca2603599644f9a7] This transitional focus is tied to IFRS 9’s role as the accounting standard for financial instruments: IFRS 9 set new accounting rules for financial instruments and replaced IAS 39, and it is effective for annual periods beginning on or after 1 January 2018 (after EU endorsement). [#TGT:9d3a529207cb52b1] So, for firms using the transition, the PRA’s capital-buffer judgement can reflect both the usual capital/risk indicators and the specific IFRS 9 transitional assessment through end-2023, in the context of IFRS 9’s post-2018 replacement of IAS 39. [#SRC:ca2603599644f9a7] [#TGT:9d3a529207cb52b1]
source_text: The PRA expects firms to hold a larger buffer or strengthen their capital position where necessary based on other factors. These include, but are not limited to: the firm’s leverage ratio; Tier 1 and total capital ratios; risks associated with double leverage; and the extent to which potentially significant risks are not captured fully as part of the stress test. Until the end of 2023, the PRA will also assess firms’ capital positions under transitional arrangements for International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) 9, 53 where firms are using these arrangements.
target_text: 53. IFRS 9 was issued in July 2014 and sets out new rules for accounting for financial instruments, replacing the rules in International Accounting Standard (IAS) 39. Following endorsement for use in the EU, IFRS 9 is effective for annual periods beginning on or after 1 January 2018. The PRA’s communications to firms on IFRS 9 are available on the Bank’s website at https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/letter/2017/transition-disclosures-for-ifrs9-financial-instruments .

question: When complying with the requirement to mark eligible deposits so they can be immediately identified, may a firm satisfy this by marking the accounts of eligible depositors, and if an account marked in this way later has a nil or negative balance, is the firm expected to remove the marker?
gold_answer: A firm can meet the immediate-identification objective for eligible deposits by applying the marker at the account level for eligible depositors, provided that approach results in eligible deposits being immediately identifiable. [#TGT:60b306349873ce31] The PRA indicates that, for the purpose of meeting Depositor Protection 11.1, marking may be achieved by marking accounts of eligible depositors that contain eligible deposits, which supports using an account marker as the operational method to achieve identification. [#SRC:91baf6dd072390d5] Once an account has been marked in this way, the PRA does not expect the firm to remove the eligible deposit marker merely because the account has a nil balance or the balance becomes negative. [#SRC:91baf6dd072390d5] In practice, the firm should implement its marking so that eligible deposits are immediately identifiable through the marker, while maintaining marker continuity on accounts even if the balance later reaches zero or goes below zero. [#TGT:60b306349873ce31] [#SRC:91baf6dd072390d5]
source_text: For the purposes of meeting Depositor Protection 11.1 , the PRA considers the marking of eligible deposits may be achieved by marking accounts of eligible depositors which contain eligible deposits. For the avoidance of doubt, where such an account has a nil balance, or the balance becomes negative, the PRA does not expect firms to remove the eligible deposit marker.
target_text: A firm must mark eligible deposits in a way that allows for the immediate identification of such deposits .

question: For Supervisory Statement 2/19 on the PRA approach to interpreting reporting and disclosure requirements and regulatory transactions forms after EU withdrawal, how should a firm reconcile the Supervisory Statement reference in the source listing with the dated Bank of England publication entry, including the applicable timing indicated?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the two entries as referring to the same Supervisory Statement and use them together to identify both the instrument and its publication timing in the context of the PRA’s approach to interpreting reporting and disclosure requirements and regulatory transactions forms after withdrawal from the EU. The source provides the core identification of the document as “Supervisory Statement (SS) 2/19” and its subject matter—how the PRA approaches interpretation of reporting and disclosure requirements and regulatory transactions forms after EU withdrawal—so it anchors what the material is and the regulatory topic it addresses [#SRC:4cab36a7d094e1aa]. The target then adds the concrete timing detail by listing “December 2020” alongside “Supervisory Statement 2/19” and associates it with a Bank of England publication page, which supports locating the relevant publication entry for that same Supervisory Statement and confirms the date to be used for internal tracking and referencing [#TGT:6be01175d4277214]. Read together, the firm can cite SS 2/19 for the interpretive approach and record December 2020 as the dated publication entry for governance, audit trails, and document control.
source_text: Supervisory Statement (SS) 2/19 ‘PRA approach to interpreting reporting and disclosure requirements and regulatory transactions forms after EU withdrawal’; 5
target_text: 5. December 2020: Supervisory Statement 2/19 – PRA approach to interpreting reporting and disclosure requirements and regulatory transactions forms after the UK’s withdrawal from the EU | Bank of England: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2019/pra-approach-to-interpreting-reporting-and-disclosure-reqs-and-reg-trans-forms-ss :

question: For a third country CRR firm, how should a firm determine whether the responsibilities described as “third country CRR firm prescribed responsibilities” are in scope, given that the scope provision states that such prescribed responsibilities do not apply? In your answer, explain what is captured by the definition of a “third country CRR firm prescribed responsibility” and how the stated non-application affects that category.
gold_answer: The definition establishes the category: subject to a stated condition, each responsibility set out in the relevant rule is treated as a “third country CRR firm prescribed responsibility” [#TGT:44007a11cde2c105]. Separately, the scope statement provides an explicit carve-out for a third country CRR firm by stating that the third country CRR firm prescribed responsibilities do not apply [#SRC:f648d10db474d8ec]. Read together, this means that even though the rule text may classify responsibilities as “third country CRR firm prescribed responsibilities” (i.e., they fall within the defined label when the definition’s condition is met), the scope provision removes their applicability to the third country CRR firm in question. Practically, the firm should (i) identify the responsibilities that would otherwise be captured by the definition as being “set out in this rule” and therefore within the defined category [#TGT:44007a11cde2c105], and then (ii) apply the scope carve-out confirming that those prescribed responsibilities are not applicable to the third country CRR firm [#SRC:f648d10db474d8ec].
source_text: (1) the third country CRR firm prescribed responsibilities in 6.2 do not apply; and
target_text: Subject to 6.3 , each of the responsibilities set out in this rule is a third country CRR firm prescribed responsibility :

question: If the PRA external audit rules apply to an undertaking’s SFCR, does the auditor need to cover how big the matching adjustment’s effect is, and how does the example about calculating the impact of changing the MA to zero (and its link to Life Technical Provisions) help explain what must be in scope?
gold_answer: Yes. When the PRA’s external audit rules apply, the scale of the matching adjustment (MA)—i.e., the extent to which it affects technical provisions—is within the audit scope. [#SRC:428012445d83f28d] The reason given is that the MA’s impact sits within the SFCR “relevant elements” that external auditors are required to form a view on. [#SRC:428012445d83f28d] The target text provides a concrete illustration of what that means in practice: it identifies as a relevant element the quantification of how the undertaking’s financial position would be affected if the MA were changed to zero. [#TGT:a160cf63fb8299cf] That example helps connect the general “relevant elements” concept to a specific MA-related calculation that is expected to be covered. [#TGT:a160cf63fb8299cf] The target text also states that the MA directly affects Life Technical Provisions, and that those Life Technical Provisions are within scope of the External Audit rule, which aligns with the source’s focus on the MA’s impact on technical provisions as audit-scoped. [#TGT:a160cf63fb8299cf] [#SRC:428012445d83f28d] Taken together, these points indicate the auditor’s scope should include both the MA’s effect on technical provisions and the SFCR-relevant quantification of the “MA to zero” impact on financial position. [#SRC:428012445d83f28d] [#TGT:a160cf63fb8299cf]
source_text: The scale of the matching adjustment (ie the extent to which the MA impacts on technical provisions) is within scope of audit where the PRA’s external audit rules apply. 6 This reflects the fact that the impact of the MA falls within the ‘relevant elements’ that external auditors of the SFCR are required to form a view on. 7
target_text: 7. For example, the quantification of the impact of a change to zero of the MA on that undertaking’s financial position is specified as a relevant element of the SFCR (External Audit 2.2(1) and Rules 3.4(1)(a) and (b) in the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook. In addition, the MA has a direct effect on Life Technical Provisions which are within scope of the External Audit rule.

question: You must not split a contract’s insurance obligations into separate parts when building the relevant portfolio, unless it is an eligible element. If you want to include only the in-payment part of an income protection contract in a matching adjustment portfolio, when is that allowed and what is not allowed, especially around recovery time risk?
gold_answer: The rule for building the relevant portfolio is that you must not split the insurance or reinsurance obligations of a contract into different parts, unless the split is within an “eligible element” [#TGT:80ba42a4e7626379]. The PRA’s matching adjustment guidance describes when an in-payment portion of an income protection contract may fit within that kind of exception: in-payment elements may be eligible for inclusion where they are separately identifiable and can be organised and managed separately in line with the referenced regulatory requirement, and the PRA expects this to allow in-payment claims under group and individual income protection policies to be permitted within MA portfolios where the claims are not subject to future premiums [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b]. The PRA also explains the underwriting risk angle: permitted underwriting risks connected to the portfolio may include recovery time risk (the risk that policyholders in receipt of income protection payments take longer to recover than expected), and unlike mortality risk there is no restriction on exposure to recovery time risk in firms’ MA portfolios [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b]. However, the PRA does not expect that recognising recovery time risk should be used to bring in liabilities other than income protection claims in payment, so splitting cannot be used to widen the portfolio beyond that scope [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b].
source_text: Matching Adjustment 2.2(2) specifies that the permitted underwriting risks connected to the portfolio of liabilities may include recovery time risk, where this is the risk that policyholders in receipt of income protection payments take longer to recover from sickness than expected. Matching Adjustment 2.3 and 2.5 provide that in-payment elements of income protection contracts may be eligible for inclusion, where they are separately identifiable and can be organised and managed separately in accordance with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations. The PRA considers that this will allow in-payment claims under both group and individual income protection policies to be permitted within MA portfolios, where the claims are not subject to future premiums. Unlike with mortality risk, there is no restriction on the exposure to recovery time risk in firms’ MA portfolios. The PRA does not expect that the inclusion of recovery time as an underwriting risk should lead to types of liabilities other than income protection claims in payment being included in MA portfolios.
target_text: For the purposes of this Part, the insurance or reinsurance obligations of an insurance or reinsurance contract must not be split into different parts when composing the relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations , other than in the case of an eligible element .

question: If the PRA does not feel confident about the home country’s resolution setup for a bank branch, what might the PRA require for a bank that already has a UK branch, and how does the Bank’s ability to resolve a branch on its own in some cases connect to that?
gold_answer: When the PRA cannot get enough comfort that the home resolution authority’s regime will produce outcomes that meet the PRA’s and the Bank’s objectives as UK resolution authority, the PRA says it is likely unwilling to host a branch from that jurisdiction. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] If the bank is already in the UK through an existing branch, the PRA indicates it may require the firm to set up a UK subsidiary instead. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] The PRA also explains that, where assurance over home state resolution arrangements is insufficient, the firm may need to be supervised more on a standalone basis in a way that matches an MPE approach to resolution. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] This focus on being able to deal with the branch or UK operations separately connects to the Bank’s stated powers: the Bank has certain resolution powers over branches, including resolving branches on a standalone basis in certain circumstances. [#TGT:5b8d0f16006f4c55] So, the PRA’s potential move toward subsidiarisation and standalone supervision for an existing branch aligns with the idea that the Bank can, where circumstances apply, take branch-level resolution action on a standalone basis. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] [#TGT:5b8d0f16006f4c55]
source_text: The PRA’s preferred approach is to gain assurance that the home resolution authority’s resolution regime will deliver the appropriate outcomes for the PRA’s and the Bank’s objectives as UK resolution authority. In the absence of adequate levels of assurance, the PRA will likely not be prepared to host such a branch from that jurisdiction. 53 In the case of an international bank operating through an existing branch, it may be required to establish a UK subsidiary. If there is insufficient assurance over the home state resolution arrangements, this may in turn mean that it would be necessary for the firm to be supervised on a more standalone basis consistent with a MPE approach to resolution.
target_text: 53. The Bank has certain resolution powers over branches, including the power to resolve branches on a standalone basis in certain circumstances.

question: If a firm is a small CRR firm or a small third country CRR firm, does it still have to state whether the institution benefits from a derogation in the Remuneration Part of the PRA Rulebook, even though certain rules do not apply to that kind of firm?
gold_answer: Yes, the institution still needs to provide information on whether it benefits from a derogation laid down in the Remuneration Part of the PRA Rulebook, because that item is explicitly framed as information to be provided about the institution’s derogation status [#SRC:8b3d59ee5a01ffc2]. Separately, the scope text says that certain listed provisions do not apply to a firm that is a small CRR firm or a small third country CRR firm [#TGT:a4ec0f032fd53c03]. Putting these together, being within the category of a small CRR firm or a small third country CRR firm affects whether the specified provisions apply, but it does not remove the need to communicate whether the institution benefits from a derogation where that information is required to be supplied. In practice, the firm should (1) confirm whether it is a small CRR firm or a small third country CRR firm for the purpose of the non-applicability statement, and (2) still include a clear statement on whether the institution benefits from a derogation under the Remuneration Part of the PRA Rulebook.
source_text: (k) information on whether the institution benefits from a derogation laid down in the Remuneration Part of the PRA Rulebook at 5.3 , and/or 12.2 (second subparagraph), and 15.A1 (3) .
target_text: 12.2 , 15.15 to 15.19 , 15.20 (2) and (3A), 15.20A to 15.23 and 15A do not apply to a firm that is a small CRR firm or a small third country CRR firm .

question: When institutions handle derivative transactions that are mapped to the commodity risk category and the transaction has more than one material risk driver, how shall the transaction be mapped across risk categories and, within the commodity risk category, how shall it be assigned to a hedging set based on the relevant risk driver?
gold_answer: Institutions must first determine whether a derivative transaction has more than one material risk driver and, if so, apply the derogation requiring mapping to more than one risk category where relevant. If all material risk drivers fall within the same risk category, the transaction is mapped only once to that category using the most material risk driver; if the material risk drivers span different risk categories, the transaction is mapped once to each relevant risk category, using the most material risk driver within each category [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. Separately, for the portion of the analysis where the transaction is mapped to the commodity risk category, institutions must then assign that transaction to one of the specified hedging sets. That hedging set assignment must be made on the basis of the nature of the transaction’s primary risk driver, or (where applicable) the most material risk driver within the commodity risk category for the relevant transactions [#SRC:820ffbb74005c855]. In practice, this means multi-risk-driver transactions may require multiple category mappings, while the commodity hedging set selection is anchored to the primary or most material commodity risk driver.
source_text: (e) transactions mapped to the commodity risk category shall be assigned to one of the following hedging sets on the basis of the nature of their primary risk driver or the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) :
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.

question: When establishing indicator monitoring to support decision-making on a solvent exit, may a firm rely on its existing management information framework and the indicator framework developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations rather than creating a new indicator set, and what specific monitoring dimensions are expected for those indicators?
gold_answer: A firm may use and tailor its existing management information framework and its indicator framework developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations to meet the relevant expectations, and it does not have to create and monitor an entirely new set of indicators solely for this purpose. [#SRC:123f8b7afeb33b32] However, whichever indicators the firm uses (including those adapted from existing frameworks), it should actively monitor both projected and actual levels, and also track the trend of those indicators. [#TGT:30201d932e512926] The monitoring is not an end in itself: the indicators, together with other relevant information, are expected to enable clear and timely decision-making about a solvent exit. [#TGT:30201d932e512926] In practice, this means the firm should (i) select indicators from its existing frameworks that can be adapted to the solvent-exit context, (ii) ensure the monitoring covers forward-looking projections and observed outcomes, and (iii) review directional movement over time so that decisions can be made promptly and with clarity. [#SRC:123f8b7afeb33b32] [#TGT:30201d932e512926]
source_text: To meet the expectations in paragraphs 2.7 and 2.8 , a firm may draw on and adapt its existing management information framework, and indicator framework developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations, 24 without necessarily creating and monitoring a new set of indicators.
target_text: A firm should monitor the projected and actual levels of these indicators, as well as their trend. These indicators, alongside other relevant information, 23 should support clear and timely decision-making regarding a solvent exit.

question: Where a firm has arrangements involving 100% remote booking into the UK, including where traders have been relocated to an overseas office or entity that remotely manages risk into the UK, what must a UK trading bank or international bank carrying on activities in the UK do to evidence appropriate control and ensure effective UK oversight of the resulting remote books, including any orphan or shared books?
gold_answer: Where a firm has arrangements involving 100% remote booking into the UK—whether arising from relocation of traders to an overseas office or entity that remotely manages risk into the UK or otherwise—the arrangements must be treated as higher-risk and subjected to greater scrutiny, supported by high levels of evidence that they are appropriately controlled [#SRC:b1b392f95f91bdcf]. In parallel, any UK trading bank or international bank (subsidiary or branch) carrying on activities in the UK that receives remote bookings must ensure there is substantive UK oversight of these remote books as a risk mitigant, with particular focus where there is no UK based trader covering the book (orphan books) [#TGT:c57c2301e31ab615]. Where the operating model includes shared books or desks with a mix of local and remote traders, the bank must clearly define these in the booking taxonomy and identify the portion of risk remote-booked into the UK so it can be subject to remote booking controls [#TGT:c57c2301e31ab615]. Taken together, the heightened evidencing expectation for 100% remote booking should be met through demonstrable UK oversight and clear taxonomy and control of remote-booked risk.
source_text: c) Whether the change may lead to traders being relocated to an overseas office or entity with the role of remotely managing risk into the UK; where the firm plans an increase in remote trading, the allocation of the number and relative seniority of traders should normally be broadly aligned with the proportion of activity managed across the locations. Where the size of business undertaken in the second location is negligible, this is unlikely to be sufficient justification to warrant the splitting of a desk. Any existing arrangements where there is 100% remote booking into the UK, irrespective of whether they result from a relocation or not, should be subjected to greater scrutiny, and require high levels of evidence that they are appropriately controlled (and see 4.25P ).
target_text: Any UK trading bank or international bank (whether a subsidiary or branch) carrying on activities in the UK that receives remote bookings should ensure that there is substantive UK oversight of these remote books as a risk mitigant, and particularly in cases where there is no UK based trader covering the book (often called ‘orphan books’). ‘Shared’ books or desks, where there is a mix of local and remote traders, should be clearly defined in the booking taxonomy and the portion of the risk remote-booked into the UK is expected to be identified and subject to remote booking controls.

question: If a firm is a UK subsidiary in an international group and may mainly rely on parental support, what does its plan need to cover about UK-specific recovery options and how quickly those options could be put in place?
gold_answer: The firm’s plan needs to cover UK-specific recovery options at the level of the UK subsidiary, even if the PRA recognises that a subsidiary may have fewer options and that parental support may be the most credible recovery option [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c]. This means the firm should not stop at describing parental support; it should consider what additional options are available locally and set out those recovery options in the plan as UK subsidiary actions [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c]. Alongside describing each recovery option, the firm should include the timelines over which the recovery options could be implemented, so the plan shows when each option could realistically be carried out [#TGT:f3e093c3fd6bc8e8]. If the firm is an O-SII, the recovery options it includes should also be consistent with what is proposed in the group plan, while still being clearly described for the UK subsidiary and paired with implementation timelines [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c] [#TGT:f3e093c3fd6bc8e8]. Together, these elements help show both what the firm could do in the UK and how quickly it could do it.
source_text: (iii) The plan should include UK specific recovery options: the PRA recognises that as subsidiaries of international groups, firms may have a more limited set of recovery options at the level of the UK subsidiary and that parental support may be the most credible recovery option. However, the PRA expects firms to consider what additional options are available at the level of the UK subsidiary and set out its recovery options against the expectations set out in Chapter 2 (i) (b) , (c) , (d) , (e) , (f) , (g) and (ii) . For O-SIIs the PRA expects these options to be consistent with what is proposed in the group plan.
target_text: Firms should include the timelines over which recovery options could be implemented.

question: For UK subsidiaries of groups based outside of the UK, how should the recovery plan be structured for usability by boards and business areas, and what additional steps should the firm take regarding UK playbooks where the PRA may request more detailed work as part of UK recovery planning?
gold_answer: A UK subsidiary of a group based outside the UK should structure its recovery plan so it is readily usable by both the board and the specific business areas that would need to use it, because the board must be able to navigate and understand the plan quickly in order to take key decisions during a stress. [#TGT:a3cffd0082b9333d] In addition, such UK subsidiaries should consider the guidance on fire drills and playbooks referenced in Chapter 2 (vi) and (vii), and treat this as relevant input when shaping the plan’s practical usability for decision-makers and users. [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e] Where the PRA explicitly asks the firm to undertake more detailed work on UK playbooks as part of its UK recovery planning work, the firm should engage with that request and contact its supervisor to discuss whether this applies to it. [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e] Taken together, this means the firm should (i) design the recovery plan’s structure to support rapid board navigation and comprehension and to be workable for the business areas that will execute it, and (ii) be prepared to deepen UK playbook work—aligned to the referenced fire drill/playbook guidance—when the PRA signals that more detailed UK playbook work is expected. [#TGT:a3cffd0082b9333d] [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e]
source_text: (vii) UK subsidiaries of groups based outside of the UK should also consider the guidance on fire drills and playbooks set out in Chapter 2 (vi) and (vii) . In some cases, the PRA may explicitly ask firms to undertake more detailed work on UK playbooks as part of their UK recovery planning work. Firms should contact their supervisor to discuss whether this applies.
target_text: The PRA expects recovery plans to be structured so that they are readily usable by both boards and the specific business areas of firms that would need to use them. It is important that the board can quickly navigate and understand the recovery plan as they will be taking the key decisions in a stress.

question: If a firm is working out surplus funds and checking whether something counts as Tier 1 own funds, what does it need to look at in Own Funds 3A and 3B, and when does it have to treat certain basic own funds items as Tier 1 (using the 3.5 and 3.6 references)?
gold_answer: The firm should connect its surplus-funds calculation work with the PRA Rulebook’s Own Funds structure, and then apply the rule that forces Tier 1 classification for certain basic own funds items when the full 3B feature set is met. [#SRC:e91fa3d6305dd52e] Specifically, the firm should use the Surplus Funds and Own Funds Parts of the PRA Rulebook when calculating surplus funds and when deciding whether it meets the criteria for Tier 1 own funds. [#SRC:e91fa3d6305dd52e] Within that, Own Funds 3A is the place to identify the relevant own funds items, while Own Funds 3B is the place to check the features that determine whether an item is classified as Tier 1. [#SRC:e91fa3d6305dd52e] For the “basic own funds items” described, the firm must treat those items as substantially having the characteristics in 3.5, assessed by taking into account the features in 3.6, and it must classify them as Tier 1 own funds when the items display all of the features set out in 3B. [#TGT:6b2cbcf4cc3413b4] So the practical sequence is: identify the item in 3A, test it against the Tier 1 feature set in 3B, and if it is one of the basic own funds items and it meets all 3B features (with the 3.5/3.6 framing), classify it as Tier 1. [#SRC:e91fa3d6305dd52e][#TGT:6b2cbcf4cc3413b4]
source_text: Firms should have regard to the Surplus Funds and Own Funds Parts of the PRA Rulebook when calculating surplus funds and considering whether they meet the criteria for classification as Tier 1 own funds. In particular, Own Funds 3A sets out a list of own funds items and Own Funds 3B the features determining classification as Tier 1 own funds.
target_text: The following basic own funds items shall be deemed to substantially possess the characteristics set out in 3.5 , taking into consideration the features set out in 3.6 , and a firm must classify them as Tier 1 own funds , where the following items display all of the features set out in 3B :

question: When constructing a matching adjustment (MA) portfolio that includes in-payment income protection claims, how should a firm reconcile the PRA’s view that in-payment elements may be eligible where separately identifiable and managed separately with the rule that insurance or reinsurance obligations must not be split into different parts except for an eligible element, and what underwriting risk exposure limits apply to recovery time risk in that context?
gold_answer: A firm may only treat part of an income protection contract separately for MA portfolio composition where that part qualifies as an eligible element, and the PRA’s discussion of “in-payment elements” is framed as potentially eligible only when they are separately identifiable and can be organised and managed separately (including in line with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations). [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b] The general rule for this Part is that insurance or reinsurance obligations under a contract must not be split into different parts when composing the relevant portfolio, except in the case of an eligible element, so any separation of an in-payment element must fit within that exception rather than being a general permission to split obligations. [#TGT:80ba42a4e7626379] In that setting, the permitted underwriting risks connected to the portfolio of liabilities may include recovery time risk, described as the risk that policyholders receiving income protection payments take longer than expected to recover from sickness. [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b] Unlike mortality risk, the PRA indicates there is no restriction on the exposure to recovery time risk in firms’ MA portfolios, but it also states it does not expect recognising recovery time risk to justify bringing in liabilities other than income protection claims in payment. [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b]
source_text: Matching Adjustment 2.2(2) specifies that the permitted underwriting risks connected to the portfolio of liabilities may include recovery time risk, where this is the risk that policyholders in receipt of income protection payments take longer to recover from sickness than expected. Matching Adjustment 2.3 and 2.5 provide that in-payment elements of income protection contracts may be eligible for inclusion, where they are separately identifiable and can be organised and managed separately in accordance with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations. The PRA considers that this will allow in-payment claims under both group and individual income protection policies to be permitted within MA portfolios, where the claims are not subject to future premiums. Unlike with mortality risk, there is no restriction on the exposure to recovery time risk in firms’ MA portfolios. The PRA does not expect that the inclusion of recovery time as an underwriting risk should lead to types of liabilities other than income protection claims in payment being included in MA portfolios.
target_text: For the purposes of this Part, the insurance or reinsurance obligations of an insurance or reinsurance contract must not be split into different parts when composing the relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations , other than in the case of an eligible element .

question: Where a firm and a group are within scope to disclose information pursuant to the specified Reporting provisions and related PRA Rulebook Articles, what must the firm ensure is additionally included in its SFCR regarding capital management, and how must that content be presented?
gold_answer: When a firm and a group are in scope to disclose information pursuant to the specified Reporting provisions and the referenced Articles of Chapter 3A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook, that disclosure context frames the broader set of information the firm is expected to address [#SRC:2ae4fedd8ca85f88]. In addition to whatever information is disclosed under those Reporting routes, the firm has a distinct SFCR obligation focused on capital management: the SFCR must go beyond the core items and include any other information that is material to the capital management of the firm. This additional material information is not to be embedded informally within other narrative; it must be presented in a dedicated, separate section of the SFCR, ensuring it is clearly identifiable as supplementary capital-management content [#TGT:6d803b1270670d13]. Read together, the scope provision clarifies the disclosure setting (information disclosed by a firm and a group under the listed Reporting provisions), while the SFCR requirement imposes an affirmative duty on the firm to capture any further material capital-management information and to structure it as a standalone section within the SFCR.
source_text: (1) Subject to (3), (4) and 4.2 , the information that a firm and a group discloses pursuant to Reporting 3.3 (5)(d), 3.4 , 3.4A , 3.5A , 3.5B , 3.6B , 3.7A to 3.7C , and Articles 7A(1) (d) and Articles 7A(1) (e) of Chapter 3A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook;
target_text: The SFCR shall include any other material information, in a separate section, regarding the capital management of the firm .

question: If a firm wants to use an insurance-group transaction (like a loan or derivative) to restructure an asset so it can go into the MA portfolio, what does the PRA expect the firm to check about (1) whether the unrestructured asset stays suitable over the life of the restructuring as conditions change, and (2) whether the unrestructured asset already fails Solvency II requirements (including the PPP)?
gold_answer: The PRA’s expectation is that a firm should only rely on an insurance-group transaction (including a loan or derivative) to restructure an asset for MA portfolio inclusion if the restructured asset can satisfy the MA eligibility conditions, and the firm should consider the underlying asset when judging whether those conditions will be met. [#TGT:85a09058df3cecad] As part of assessing the suitability of the restructuring arrangements, the firm is expected to start by asking whether the asset in its unrestructured form is likely to remain appropriate over time, in a way that matches the duration of the restructuring arrangement and anticipates that operating conditions may change. [#SRC:0a3517a57344a4ca] The PRA also indicates a restriction: it would not expect firms to use arrangements described in paragraph 2.55 (or arrangements that effectively do the same thing) for assets that, before restructuring, would not meet all applicable Solvency II requirements, including PPP requirements. [#TGT:85a09058df3cecad] Finally, because some assets may be inherently infeasible to restructure into MA-eligible assets, the firm should be able to demonstrate that it can place sufficient reliance on the restructuring arrangements to ensure the MA eligibility conditions continue to be satisfied over time. [#TGT:85a09058df3cecad]
source_text: In assessing the suitability of arrangements set out in paragraphs 2.55 to 2.56 above in this context, the PRA expects firms first to consider whether the unrestructured asset is likely to remain appropriate over time, consistent with the duration of the restructuring arrangement, and as operating conditions might change. Examples of assets that may not be a suitable match for the liabilities of the MA portfolio include:
target_text: The extent to which transactions within the insurance group (including loans or derivatives) can be used to restructure assets in order to include them in the MA portfolio depends on whether the restructured assets thereby created can satisfy the MA eligibility conditions. The PRA expects firms to have regard to the underlying assets being restructured when they consider whether the MA eligibility conditions will be satisfied. The PRA would not expect firms to apply arrangements as set out in paragraph 2.55 above, or arrangements that in substance have that effect, to assets that, in unrestructured form, would in any event not meet all applicable Solvency II requirements, including those of the PPP. The PRA notes that some assets by their very nature may have characteristics that make it infeasible to restructure them as MA eligible assets, and expects firms to be able to demonstrate that sufficient reliance can be placed upon restructuring arrangements to ensure the continuing satisfaction of the MA eligibility conditions.

question: For firms within the scope of the PRA’s stated expectations on marking eligible deposits and accounts, what must a firm do to ensure eligible deposits can be identified without delay, and how does that obligation align with the chapter’s intended application?
gold_answer: Where the chapter applies, it frames the PRA’s expectations for how firms will approach the marking of eligible deposits and accounts, setting the scope and context for what firms are expected to implement in practice [#SRC:1dd0f14a0bbf4e5d]. Within that scoped framework, the operative requirement is that a firm must implement a marking approach for eligible deposits that enables those deposits to be identified immediately, i.e., the marking must be designed so that eligible deposits can be recognised without delay when needed [#TGT:60b306349873ce31]. Read together, the source establishes that the topic is specifically the marking of eligible deposits (and related accounts) and that the PRA is articulating expectations for firms’ processes in this area [#SRC:1dd0f14a0bbf4e5d], while the target provides the concrete compliance outcome that the marking must achieve—immediate identifiability of eligible deposits [#TGT:60b306349873ce31]. Accordingly, a firm should treat the chapter’s expectations as the contextual guide for designing and operating its marking arrangements, but ensure the implemented method meets the mandatory standard of immediate identification.
source_text: This chapter sets out the PRA’s expectations of how firms will mark eligible deposits and accounts and is intended to be read together with Chapters 11 and 13 of the Depositor Protection Part .
target_text: A firm must mark eligible deposits in a way that allows for the immediate identification of such deposits .

question: When a firm calibrates a residential mortgage rating system by uplifting internal observed default rates to a long-run average and uses an embedded calculation mechanism that changes the PD applied to exposures with a given set of characteristics, how must the firm treat that mechanism for recalibration purposes, and what cyclicality assumption must it apply when grade-level internal observed default rates are unavailable (including how the PRA may vary that expectation)?
gold_answer: A firm should treat any embedded calculation mechanism in its rating system that changes the PD applied to exposures with a given set of characteristics as a recalibration, rather than as an intended feature of rating system design, because the PRA expects such recalibrations to be rare and symptomatic of failures in the rating system’s assumptions [#SRC:5f859b5bac10db27]. In parallel, when calibrating residential mortgage rating systems by uplifting internal observed default rates to a long-run average, the firm should assume that the cyclicality of each rating system is no more than 30% in years where grade-level internal observed default rates are not available, as this cap is the PRA’s expectation for imputing missing historical default rates [#TGT:8705f442785054e1]. The firm should also reflect the PRA’s expectation that, when assigning long-run average default rates to each rating grade, at least 70% of the portfolio change in default rate is assumed to reflect grade-level changes in default rate (with the remaining portion attributable to grade migration) [#TGT:8705f442785054e1]. The PRA indicates this expectation may be adjusted if it judges the risk of under-calibration has changed [#TGT:8705f442785054e1].
source_text: The PRA expects recalibrations of rating systems applying the cyclicality assumptions set out in paragraph 12.4 to be rare and to be symptomatic of failures of the rating system’s assumptions rather than part of rating system design. For these purposes any calculation mechanism embedded in a rating system that changes the PD applied to exposures with a given set of characteristics should be treated as a recalibration. The PRA expects that any recalibration of such a rating system would include:
target_text: In the PRA’s experience, firms often have difficulty in practice in understanding the cyclicality of their residential mortgage rating systems. To mitigate the risk of under-calibration of these rating systems due to inaccurate estimation of their cyclicality, the PRA expects that when firms calibrate their residential mortgage rating systems by uplifting internal observed default rates to a long-run average, they should do so on the assumption that the cyclicality of each rating system is no more than 30% in those years where grade level internal observed default rates are not available. This cyclicality cap is the PRA’s expectation of what firms should assume is the maximum level of cyclicality when imputing missing historical default rates. If 30% of the change in portfolio default rates comes from grade migration the remaining 70% would come from change in default rates within grades. Therefore when calibrating the long-run average default rates to assign to each rating grade the PRA expects firms to assume that at least 70% of the portfolio change in default rate reflects grade level changes in default rate. This level reflects the PRA’s current view of an appropriately conservative assumption for rating system cyclicality in light of recent experience. This expectation may be adjusted by the PRA if it judges that there has been a change in the risk of under-calibration.

question: If a relevant third-country firm is preparing the whole-firm liquidity information the PRA expects, what LCR materials must it include from what it already reports to its home state supervisor (HSS), and what does it mean that this is based on the HSS’s implementation of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision’s 2013 Liquidity Coverage Requirement?
gold_answer: When a relevant third-country firm prepares the whole-firm liquidity information the PRA expects, it should build the submission from the data it reports to its home state supervisor (HSS). The PRA expects the firm to provide the information in a single, consolidated currency and, if the firm provides it to the HSS, also on a significant currency basis. For the LCR part specifically, the firm should include the LCR-related data it reports to the HSS, including the completed LCR template and any other additional liquidity reports it submits to the HSS [#SRC:432f97ed6f63cee5]. The reference point for what “LCR” means in this context is that it is based on the HSS’s implementation of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision’s introduction of the Liquidity Coverage Requirement in 2013, so the firm’s LCR materials should reflect how its HSS has implemented that 2013 requirement [#TGT:b05def7c40876dda].
source_text: The PRA expects relevant third-country firms to submit liquidity information at the whole-firm level, based upon data which is reported to the firm’s home state supervisor (‘HSS’). Data should be provided in a single, consolidated currency and where this is provided to the HSS, also on a significant currency basis. In particular, this should include data reported to the firm’s HSS that relates to the liquidity coverage ratio (LCR) 2 and in particular the completed LCR template and any other additional liquidity reports submitted to the HSS. 3
target_text: 2. Based on the HSS’s implementation of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision’s introduction of Liquidity Coverage Requirement (LCR) in 2013.

question: When determining the amount of the long-term insurance liability for each contract, must the calculation be prospective, and in what limited circumstances may a retrospective calculation be used instead to determine the liabilities?
gold_answer: For each contract, the amount of the long-term insurance liability must be determined using a prospective calculation, establishing the default method that applies on a contract-by-contract basis [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb]. A retrospective calculation is not a free alternative to that requirement; it may only be applied to determine the liabilities in narrowly defined situations tied to the feasibility and prudence of the prospective approach [#TGT:30f622a929df3844]. Specifically, a retrospective calculation may be used where a prospective method cannot be applied to a particular type of contract or benefit, which functions as an exception to the otherwise mandatory prospective determination for each contract [#TGT:30f622a929df3844] read together with [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb]. Alternatively, even if a prospective method could be applied, a retrospective calculation may be used where it can be demonstrated that the resulting amount of liabilities would be no lower than would be required by a prudent prospective calculation, ensuring the retrospective outcome is at least as conservative as the prudent prospective benchmark [#TGT:30f622a929df3844].
source_text: Subject to 7.2 , 7.3 and 7.4 , the amount of the long-term insurance liability must be determined for each contract by a prospective calculation.
target_text: A retrospective calculation may only be applied to determine the liabilities where a prospective method cannot be applied to a particular type of contract or benefit, or where it can be demonstrated that the resulting amount of liabilities would be no lower than would be required by a prudent prospective calculation.

question: When Institutions disclose the information required across the relevant disclosure titles, how must they present those disclosures in terms of format and location, and how must the risk management objectives and policies disclosures be structured across separate categories of risk, including the risks referred to in the applicable Title?
gold_answer: Institutions must ensure that the full set of required disclosures is made available in electronic format and consolidated in a single medium or location, rather than dispersed across multiple places. That single medium or location must take the form of either a standalone document that serves as a readily accessible source of prudential information for users, or a distinctive, easily identifiable section included in or appended to the institutions’ financial statements or financial reports. Within that same disclosure package, Institutions must also provide disclosures on their risk management objectives and policies, and they must do so for each separate category of risk, explicitly covering the risks referred to in the applicable Title. In practice, this means the electronic, single-location disclosure vehicle must be organized so users can readily find, by risk category, the institution’s stated objectives and policies, while still meeting the overarching requirement to include all information required under the relevant titles in one accessible place [#SRC:8422ed9edcda5caa] and to cover each separate category of risk, including the risks referred to in the Title [#TGT:dedbe720c755ba15].
source_text: Institutions shall disclose all the information required under Titles II and III in electronic format and in a single medium or location. The single medium or location shall be a standalone document that provides a readily accessible source of prudential information for users of that information or a distinctive section included in or appended to the institutions' financial statements or financial reports containing the required disclosures and being easily identifiable to those users.
target_text: Institutions shall disclose their risk management objectives and policies for each separate category of risk, including the risks referred to in this Title. These disclosures shall include:

question: If the PRA puts off a class A2 member’s recapitalisation payment levy share because paying now would harm the firm’s liquidity or solvency, how long can that delay last, can it be extended, and when does the firm have to pay the deferred amount?
gold_answer: The deferred amount has to be paid when paying it no longer puts the firm’s liquidity and solvency at risk, and the PRA’s deferral cannot last more than six months at a time, although it can be renewed if the firm requests it. [#SRC:f026573295165d20] [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] In other words, the payment timing is linked to the firm’s financial condition: once the payment would not jeopardise liquidity and solvency, the contribution becomes due. [#SRC:f026573295165d20] The PRA can defer the obligation (fully or partly) only where it considers the contribution would jeopardise the liquidity or solvency of the firm, and this applies to a class A2 member’s share of a recapitalisation payment levy. [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] The six-month limit is a hard cap on any single deferral period, but the firm can ask for a renewal, which allows the deferral to continue beyond six months through renewed periods. [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] So the firm should track both (i) whether the liquidity/solvency risk has ended (which triggers payment) and (ii) the end date of the current six-month deferral period (which may require a renewal request). [#SRC:f026573295165d20] [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b]
source_text: Any contributions deferred pursuant to 46.2 or 46.2A shall be paid when the payment no longer jeopardises the liquidity and solvency of the firm .
target_text: The PRA may defer, in whole or in part, a class A2 member’s obligation to pay a share of a recapitalisation payment levy if the PRA considers that such contributions would jeopardise the liquidity or solvency of the firm . Such deferral shall not be granted for a longer period than six months but may be renewed upon request of the firm .

question: When a firm is preparing the report that must be submitted periodically under Chapter 3 and then summarised for periodic publication under Chapter 4, how should it determine what the PRA expects for the report’s content and format, and how does the PRA handle the timing of the submission and disclosure?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the report it must submit periodically under Chapter 3 as a report whose content and format are governed by the PRA’s expectations set out in the chapter addressing that Chapter 3 report, and it should plan its submission and related disclosure around dates the PRA will provide in advance. [#SRC:67e3fc728b0c6db8] Specifically, firms have an obligation to submit reports on a periodic basis under Chapter 3 and to publish a summary of that report periodically under Chapter 4, so the reporting and disclosure cycle includes both submission and a separate summary publication step. [#SRC:67e3fc728b0c6db8] For the Chapter 3 report itself, the relevant expectations for what the report should contain and how it should be presented are set out in the chapter that describes the PRA’s expectations on the content and format of a firm’s report required under Resolution Assessment Chapter 3. [#TGT:64f5e172de569a7c] In operational terms, the firm should align its internal drafting and review process to those content/format expectations for the Chapter 3 report, and then schedule both the Chapter 3 submission and the Chapter 4 summary publication using the expected dates that the PRA will communicate ahead of time. [#SRC:67e3fc728b0c6db8] [#TGT:64f5e172de569a7c]
source_text: Firms are required to submit reports periodically under Chapter 3 of the rules and publish a summary of that report periodically under Chapter 4 of the rules. The PRA will communicate the expected dates for firms’ submission and disclosure in advance.
target_text: This chapter sets out the PRA’s expectations on the content and format of a firm’s report required under Resolution Assessment Chapter 3.

question: When an institution maps a derivative transaction with more than one material risk driver to multiple risk categories, how must it determine whether it has a long or short position in the most material risk driver within each mapped risk category, based on the condition that the transaction’s market value moves with increases in that risk driver’s value?
gold_answer: Institutions must first apply the mapping requirement for derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver by assigning the transaction to more than one risk category, unless all material risk drivers fall within a single risk category, in which case the transaction is mapped only once to that category using the most material risk driver in that category [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. Once the relevant risk category (or categories) is determined, the institution must identify, within each mapped risk category, the primary risk driver or the most material risk driver used as the basis for mapping. The institution then determines position direction by assessing how the transaction’s market value responds to an increase in the value of that risk driver: if the market value increases when the risk driver’s value increases, the position in that risk driver is long; if the market value decreases when the risk driver’s value increases, the position is short [#SRC:c6e60ca38b4dc301]. This long/short determination is therefore performed per mapped risk category, aligned to the most material risk driver selected for that category under the mapping approach.
source_text: For the purposes of this Section, a long position in the primary risk driver or in the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) means that the market value of the transaction increases when the value of that risk driver increases and a short position in the primary risk driver or in the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) means that the market value of the transaction decreases when the value of that risk driver increases.
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.

question: For a firm with a TMTP permission, how must the firm determine the permissible range for the transitional deduction it applies, and how is the “maximum amount” defined for that purpose? Where the firm elects to apply less than that maximum, what disclosure and supervisory-sharing steps does the PRA expect, and how must the firm ensure consistency of this approach across its Solvency II reporting and governance materials?
gold_answer: For all firms with a TMTP permission, the firm must ensure the amount of the transitional deduction it applies sits within a defined range: it must be no less than zero and no more than the maximum amount [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c]. The “maximum amount” for this purpose is defined as the maximum number derived either from the TMTP method in Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions or from the legacy approach set out in the relevant firm’s permission [#TGT:f321e44c98b40d33]. If the firm decides to apply less than that maximum, the PRA expects the firm to include both the maximum amount and the actual TMTP amount in the notes to market disclosures and to share the same information with its supervision team [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c].
