question: When exposures from the trading book and the non-trading book are adjusted, what must Institutions produce to evidence prudent valuation compliance—specifically, what breakdown of the prudent valuation adjustment is required by risk type and by book, and how must that reporting align with the obligation that all fair-valued trading and non-trading book positions are subject to prudent valuation standards and achieve an appropriate degree of certainty?
gold_answer: Institutions must connect their prudent valuation governance and reporting so that, where exposures from the trading book and the non-trading book are adjusted, they can present a clear breakdown of the amounts making up the institution’s prudent valuation adjustment. That breakdown must identify the constituent elements by type of risks and must also show the total of those constituent elements separately for trading book positions and for non-trading book positions [#SRC:2523899445035439]. This reporting obligation sits within, and should be used to demonstrate, the broader requirement that all trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value are subject to the applicable prudent valuation standards, and that the prudent valuation of trading book positions in particular achieves an appropriate degree of certainty given the dynamic nature of those positions, prudential soundness considerations, and the role and operation of capital requirements for both trading and fair-valued non-trading positions [#TGT:fab620639def0122]. In practice, Institutions should ensure the breakdown is consistent with how positions are classified between books and how fair-valued positions are brought within the prudent valuation standards, so the risk-type components and book-level totals support the required certainty objective.
source_text: (e) for exposures from the trading book and the non-trading book that are adjusted in accordance with Article 34 and Article 105 , a breakdown of the amounts of the constituent elements of an institution's prudent valuation adjustment, by type of risks, and the total of constituent elements separately for the trading book and non-trading book positions;
target_text: Institutions shall ensure that all trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value shall be subject to the standards for prudent valuation specified in this Article and in Chapter 4 of the Trading Book (CRR) Part of the PRA Rulebook. Institutions shall in particular ensure that the prudent valuation of their trading book positions achieves an appropriate degree of certainty having regard to the dynamic nature of trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value, the demands of prudential soundness and the mode of operation and purpose of capital requirements in respect of trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value.

question: If the society is transferring to a specially formed successor company, what must the transfer terms do so the society stops holding shares by the time it dissolves, and what notices and timing must the society follow for the vesting date and any later dissolution date so it can dispose of those shares?
gold_answer: The transfer terms must include provisions that make sure the society stops holding any shares in the specially formed successor company by the date on which the society is to dissolve [#SRC:6b46a0ab65f37c08]. The society then has to follow the vesting-date and dissolution process that governs when dissolution happens and how share disposal can be completed. Once the PRA has confirmed the transfer, it will notify the FCA and the society, and the society must notify both the PRA and the FCA of the vesting date no later than seven days before that date [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8]. If the society does not give a notice of a later dissolution date, dissolution occurs on the vesting date; however, if it is necessary to help dispose of the society’s shares in its successor, the society may include in its vesting-date notice a later dissolution date, and dissolution will occur on that later date [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8]. If the society uses that later-dissolution option, it must stop transacting any business from the vesting date except what is necessary to dispose of its shares, supporting the requirement that it no longer holds shares by dissolution [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8] [#SRC:6b46a0ab65f37c08].
source_text: The terms of the transfer must include provision to secure that the society ceases to hold any shares in the specially formed successor company by the date on which the society is to dissolve (Section 100(11) of the 1986 Act). The provisions of the 1986 Act concerning the dissolution of the society and the disposal of any shares in its successor are discussed in section ‘ Notification and Dissolution ’.
target_text: When the PRA has confirmed a transfer (whether voluntary or under direction) it will notify the FCA and the society concerned. Section 97(8) of the 1986 Act requires the society to notify the PRA and the FCA of the vesting date, and it must do so no later than seven days before that date, and, unless a notice is given under subsection (10), subsection (9) provides that the society shall be dissolved on that date. Subsection (10) provides that, if necessary for the purpose of facilitating the disposal of its shares in its successor, the society may include, in the notice of the vesting date, notice of a later date for the dissolution of the society, and it is on this later date that the society is dissolved. A society which gives such a notice must cease to transact any business as from the notified vesting date, except such as may be necessary to dispose of its shares in its successor.

question: When stress conditions change, what do TWD firms need to be able to refresh in the TWD option within days or weeks, and what sensitivity analysis capability must they have to show how key market factors in the TWD scenario and related assumptions and judgments could affect capital, liquidity, and RBLs?
gold_answer: TWD firms are expected to be able to use their data refresh and full plan refresh capabilities to refresh the material components of the TWD option that require judgement, and to do this within a timeframe that can be as short as days or as long as weeks depending on the nature and extent of the stress [#SRC:58ebd6a4c26d1aaa]. This refresh should not be treated as a purely administrative update; it should include analysis that tests the impact of updated inputs. Specifically, TWD firms should have the ability to perform sensitivity analyses of the key market factors in the TWD scenario, assumptions, and judgments where those changes could have a material impact on capital and liquidity projections and on RBLs [#TGT:5fd58dcf50062ad4]. In practice, that means the refreshed, judgement-based elements of the option should be accompanied by sensitivities that show how changes in the relevant market-factor assumptions and judgments would move projected capital and liquidity outcomes and the associated RBL effects.
source_text: The PRA expects that TWD firms’ data refresh and full plan refresh capabilities can be utilised such that TWD firms are able to perform a refresh of the material components of the TWD option that require judgement, between a matter of days and a matter of weeks (depending on the nature and extent of the stress). 29 This should include sensitivity analyses of updates to the factors set out in paragraphs 4.49 - 4.51 .
target_text: TWD firms should have the ability to perform sensitivity analyses of the key market factors set out in the TWD scenario, assumptions, and judgments that could have a material impact on capital and liquidity projections and on RBLs. question: How must a critical third party demonstrate, through regular scenario testing, that it can continue providing each systemic third party service within its appropriate maximum tolerable level of disruption during a severe but plausible operational disruption, and how must that testing be integrated into its obligation to manage effectively CTP operational incidents?
gold_answer: A critical third party must run regular scenario tests that are designed to evidence its ability to keep providing each systemic third party service within its appropriate maximum tolerable level of disruption when faced with a severe but plausible disruption to its operations [#SRC:ab41ddd44c248825]. Those tests should be structured so they directly support the critical third party’s duty to manage effectively CTP operational incidents, because the incident-management obligation requires the firm to handle operational incidents in an effective manner and the scenario testing is the mechanism for validating that capability under stressed conditions [#TGT:52897713a3fe26c0]. In practice, the critical third party should ensure the scenarios are relevant to operational disruptions that could trigger CTP operational incidents, and that the test outcomes can be used to confirm whether continuity of each systemic third party service remains within the maximum tolerable level of disruption referenced in the continuity requirement [#SRC:ab41ddd44c248825]. The linkage is that effective incident management should be demonstrable through tested operational resilience, rather than assumed, and the regularity of testing supports ongoing readiness to manage incidents effectively [#TGT:52897713a3fe26c0].
source_text: As part of its obligation under 5.1 , a critical third party must carry out regular scenario testing of its ability to continue providing each systemic third party service within its appropriate maximum tolerable level of disruption (set in accordance with 4.10 (2)) in the event of a severe but plausible disruption to its operations.

question: When applying Chapter 4 of the Matching Adjustment Part of the PRA Rulebook (including Rule 4.6), how should a firm treat the fundamental spread component—specifically the portion reflecting risks retained by the firm—given that the fundamental spread is calculated under rules 4.10 to 4.17?
gold_answer: A firm must exclude from the matching adjustment any fundamental spread element that reflects risks retained by the firm, even where the fundamental spread itself is determined using the calculation approach in rules 4.10 to 4.17. [#TGT:9bbf6a9cc239d53c] This exclusion is framed within Chapter 4 of the Matching Adjustment Part of the PRA Rulebook, where Rule 4.6 (restating relevant IRPR provisions) establishes that the matching adjustment is not permitted to include the fundamental spread to the extent it represents risks the firm keeps. [#SRC:9242ee9283fd69c0] In practice, the firm may still calculate the fundamental spread in accordance with 4.10 to 4.17, but it must ensure that the matching adjustment outcome does not incorporate the part of that fundamental spread that corresponds to retained risks. [#TGT:9bbf6a9cc239d53c] The compliance focus is therefore on the composition of the matching adjustment (what it includes or excludes), not on altering the prescribed method for calculating the fundamental spread under 4.10 to 4.17. [#SRC:9242ee9283fd69c0]
source_text: Chapter 4 of the Matching Adjustment Part of the PRA Rulebook, which restates the relevant provisions of the IRPR regulations, sets out (at Rule 4.6 ) that the matching adjustment must not include the fundamental spread reflecting the risks retained by the firm.
target_text: The matching adjustment must not include the fundamental spread (as calculated in accordance with 4.10 to 4.17 ) reflecting the risks retained by the firm .

question: Where a firm must have policies and procedures to ensure compliance by its managers, employees and appointed representatives (or tied agents) and to counter financial crime risk, what specific governance responsibility is described for safeguarding the independence of, and overseeing the performance of, the compliance function (including oversight of a person approved by the FCA to perform the compliance oversight function on behalf of the firm)?
gold_answer: The firm’s compliance framework should combine (i) firm-wide policies and procedures designed to secure regulatory compliance and reduce financial crime risk, and (ii) a clearly assigned governance responsibility for the compliance function itself. The firm must have adequate policies and procedures that are sufficient to ensure compliance of the firm, including its managers, employees and appointed representatives (or, where applicable, tied agents), with obligations under the regulatory system, and that also address the risk the firm could be used to further financial crime. [#TGT:5ca4886f7aeb4304] In addition to that firm-wide control environment, there is an explicit responsibility for safeguarding the independence of the compliance function and overseeing its performance. [#SRC:ee565fa3af708789] This oversight responsibility extends to monitoring the performance of a person approved by the FCA to perform the compliance oversight function on behalf of the firm, and it is framed as being carried out in accordance with Compliance and Internal Audit 2 (PR K). [#SRC:ee565fa3af708789] Taken together, the policies/procedures obligation sets the baseline for compliance and financial crime controls across relevant personnel, while the governance responsibility ensures the compliance function remains independent and effectively supervised, including where an FCA-approved individual performs compliance oversight for the firm. [#TGT:5ca4886f7aeb4304] [#SRC:ee565fa3af708789]
source_text: (16) responsibility for safeguarding the independence of, and overseeing the performance of, the compliance function, including the performance of a person approved by the FCA to perform the compliance oversight function on behalf of the firm , in accordance with Compliance and Internal Audit 2 (PR K) ;
target_text: A firm must establish, implement and maintain adequate policies and procedures sufficient to ensure compliance of the firm including its managers, employees and appointed representatives (or where applicable, tied agents ) with its obligations under the regulatory system and for countering the risk that the firm might be used to further financial crime .

question: In solvent exit planning, what must a firm do regarding deposits and timing/resources, and how does this interact with the position that a solvent exit may not involve liquidation—particularly where the firm is a building society that will cease to meet the principal purpose test and may need dissolution steps under the Building Societies Act 1986?
gold_answer: A firm’s solvent exit planning should be structured to ensure it can stop its PRA-regulated deposit-taking in an orderly way while remaining solvent, and it should treat the transfer and/or repayment of all deposits as a core deliverable of that process. [#SRC:a9dcecc8a5a3b33a] In practice, the firm should build in sufficient time and resources so it can meet liabilities as they fall due while it transfers and/or repays all deposits, and it should plan for the solvent exit to conclude with the removal of deposit-taking activity from the firm’s Part 4A permission or the cancellation of the firm’s Part 4A permission (i.e., removal of the firm’s Part 4A PRA permission). [#SRC:a9dcecc8a5a3b33a] At the same time, the firm should not assume that completing a solvent exit necessarily means liquidation, because whether liquidation occurs depends on the circumstances. [#TGT:401295982d2ab654] Where the firm is a building society, it should explicitly link its deposit transfer/repayment plan to the consequence that doing so will cause it to cease meeting the principal purpose test, and it should therefore also take into account any steps necessary for it to be dissolved under the Building Societies Act 1986. [#TGT:401295982d2ab654]
source_text: A solvent exit means the process through which a firm ceases its PRA-regulated activities while remaining solvent. 2 The firm should transfer 3 or repay (or both) all deposits as part of its solvent exit. 4 In the firm’s solvent exit planning, it should build in sufficient time and resources to support the firm in meeting liabilities when they fall due and in transferring and/or repaying all deposits. At a point after this, a solvent exit will end with the removal of deposit-taking activity from the firm’s Part 4A permission, or with the cancellation of the firm’s Part 4A permission (hereinafter referred to as the removal of the firm’s Part 4A PRA permission). 5
target_text: 4. A solvent exit does not necessarily result in the liquidation of the firm, as it depends on the circumstances. If the firm is a building society, the transfer and/or repayment of all deposits will mean it ceases to meet the principal purpose test. Therefore, a building society should also take into account steps which are necessary for it to be dissolved under the Building Societies Act 1986.

question: If a firm is not a small CRR firm, a credit union or a third country CRR firm, what does it have to allocate, and how do you know which items count as “prescribed responsibilities” that must be allocated to one or more persons who perform?
gold_answer: If the firm is in scope (meaning it is a firm other than a small CRR firm, a credit union or a third country CRR firm), it has a clear duty: it must allocate each of the prescribed responsibilities to one or more persons who perform [#SRC:936b595d900da181]. The key step is identifying what “prescribed responsibilities” are, because that determines what must be allocated. The definition provides that link by stating that every responsibility set out in the relevant rule is a prescribed responsibility [#TGT:a05fb83553247826]. Putting the two together, the firm should treat the responsibilities that the rule itself sets out as the full list of prescribed responsibilities, and then ensure each one is allocated to at least one person who performs. In other words, the definition tells you what belongs in the “prescribed responsibilities” bucket, and the obligation tells you what to do with everything in that bucket: allocate each item to one or more persons who perform, provided the firm is not in one of the excluded categories. [#SRC:936b595d900da181] [#TGT:a05fb83553247826]
source_text: (1) A firm (other than a small CRR firm , a credit union or a third country CRR firm ) must allocate each of the prescribed responsibilities in 4.1 (13) to (19) to one or more persons who perform:
target_text: Each of the responsibilities set out in this rule is a prescribed responsibility :

question: If a firm has client or trust accounts held for beneficiaries that might include eligible deposits, what must it do so those accounts can be spotted right away, and how quickly must it be able to send the PRA or FSCS the separated details of eligible versus ineligible accounts when asked?
gold_answer: The firm must mark the relevant accounts so they can be immediately identified—this includes client accounts and trust accounts held on behalf of beneficiaries that contain or may contain eligible deposits [#TGT:68113e9f6b9da4d1]. Beyond putting that marking in place, the firm must also have the ability to provide the PRA or the FSCS with the details of eligible and/or ineligible accounts, with eligible and ineligible accounts separately identified, in a format consistent with the relevant rule and the statement [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc]. The timing requirement is that the firm must be able to make those details available within twelve hours from the point when the PRA or the FSCS makes the request [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc]. In practice, this means the marking requirement supports immediate recognition of the accounts in scope, and the firm’s systems and processes must also support rapid production and delivery of the underlying account information, separated by eligibility status, to the PRA or FSCS on demand.
source_text: The PRA expects that in compliance with the requirement in Depositor Protection 11.1 to 11.2 to mark eligible deposits/accounts ‘in a way that allows for the immediate identification of such deposits’, a firm must be able to make the details of such eligible and/or ineligible accounts (separately identified) available to the PRA or FSCS in a format consistent with the relevant rule and this statement and within twelve hours from the point of a request from the PRA or the FSCS.
target_text: A firm must mark accounts (including client accounts and trust accounts) which are held on behalf of beneficiaries and which contain or may contain eligible deposits in a way that allows immediate identification of such accounts.

question: A firm must record what it needs to deliver each important business service. Can it use its end-to-end mapping of important business services to help document and map intragroup and other dependencies, and how does that fit with what it must identify and document?
gold_answer: A firm must identify and document, for each of its important business services, the necessary people, processes, technology, facilities and information required to deliver that service [#TGT:b33e7a291295fbdf]. That requirement means the firm’s records should show the key inputs and enablers for delivery, not just a high-level description of the service. Separately, firms are permitted to leverage their end-to-end mapping of important business services to document and map their intragroup and other dependencies [#SRC:47c57621ff7696dd]. Used together, this means the firm can take the end-to-end mapping it already has for important business services and use it as a practical tool to support the required documentation: it can help the firm organise and evidence how people, processes, technology, facilities and information connect across the group or other dependency relationships. The obligation sets what must be documented for each service, and the permission allows the firm to use its end-to-end mapping work to document and map the dependency aspects that sit within that broader documentation.
source_text: Firms may also leverage their end-to-end mapping of important business services under Chapter 4 of the Operational Resilience – CRR Firms and Operational Resilience – Solvency II Parts of the PRA Rulebook to document and map their intragroup and other dependencies.
target_text: As part of its obligation under 3.1 , a firm must identify and document the necessary people, processes, technology, facilities and information required to deliver each of its important business services .

question: If a firm wants to back TPs with an intragroup loan to another group company, what does it need to show about how the asset is invested, and why does the PRA say it is hard to prove this kind of loan is suitable?
gold_answer: To use an intragroup loan as an asset backing TPs, the firm needs to be able to show that the asset is invested in a way that matches the nature and duration of the firm’s insurance and reinsurance liabilities and that it is in the best interests of all policyholders, while also considering any disclosed policy objectives. [#SRC:afb7633ef682266c] The PRA highlights that intragroup loans (and similar participations or arrangements) can be problematic under this standard because they may benefit shareholders without necessarily benefiting policyholders. [#TGT:19e81bc332eae024] The PRA also notes a specific risk: the issuer of the loan may be less willing or able to enforce repayment, particularly for upstream loans, which can undermine the case that the arrangement protects policyholders’ interests. [#TGT:19e81bc332eae024] Because of these concerns, the PRA expects there is a high hurdle for firms to demonstrate that intragroup loans and participations are in policyholders’ best interests, and therefore a high hurdle to demonstrate they are appropriate for covering TPs. [#TGT:19e81bc332eae024] This means the firm’s explanation must satisfy both the general investment standard for TP-backing assets and the PRA’s heightened scrutiny for intragroup transactions. [#SRC:afb7633ef682266c] [#TGT:19e81bc332eae024]
source_text: In respect of assets backing TPs, the PPP requires that these must be invested ‘in a manner appropriate to the nature and duration of the firm’s insurance and reinsurance liabilities and in the best interests of all policyholders, taking into account any disclosed policy objectives’. 39
target_text: The requirement for assets backing TPs to be invested in policyholders’ best interests has particular implications for certain intragroup transactions such as intragroup loans and participations or arrangements to that effect. Investments in, or loans to, other group companies may be in the interests of shareholders but they may not necessarily be in the best interests of policyholders. For example, the issuers of loans may be less willing or able to enforce repayment, particularly where loans are upstream. The PRA expects that it would be a high hurdle for firms to demonstrate that intragroup loans and participations are in the best interests of policyholders and, as such, a high hurdle to demonstrate that they are appropriate for covering TPs.

question: If a firm’s MA asset gets upgraded, can it keep the asset in the MA portfolio, and how much of the asset’s cash flows can it still count when its ‘sufficient compensation’ test is built around matching the relevant MA liabilities and being able to buy a replacement asset of at least the original quality?
gold_answer: Yes, the PRA indicates the firm would not necessarily have to take the upgraded asset out of the MA portfolio, but that depends on whether the firm’s own ‘sufficient compensation’ criteria are set up to handle foreseeable events like an upgrade and are effective for judging whether compensation is sufficient. [#SRC:3c15a9bfcd564fbd] The PRA also describes a way those criteria may be constructed: by linking them to the relevant MA liabilities being matched by the recognised asset cash flows and to the firm’s ability to buy a replacement asset of at least as good quality as the original if the issuer changes the cash flows, so the matching can continue. [#TGT:af842f40700e6ff3] Under that approach, the firm may recognise only part of the asset’s cash flows—specifically, it can continue to recognise cash flows up to the level of the contractual compensation payable—so that compensation remains sufficient to replace the cash flows needed to match the relevant MA eligible liabilities. [#SRC:3c15a9bfcd564fbd] The firm is expected to be able to show the same level of confidence in its ability to replace cash flows as in the earlier assessment referenced in the TARGET passage, and the partial-recognition approach is described as being subject to the partial-recognition considerations referenced there. [#TGT:af842f40700e6ff3]
source_text: The PRA expects firms to consider how their own criteria for assessing ‘sufficient compensation’ cater for foreseeable events such as an asset being upgraded. The PRA considers that in such upgrade events, a firm would not necessarily need to remove the asset from the MA portfolio, if its own criteria provide for this (and to the extent that those criteria were effective in assessing whether compensation would be sufficient, taking into account paragraph 2.37 above). For example, where sufficiency of compensation criteria follow the approach described in paragraph 2.41 above, the firm might continue to recognise the asset’s cash flows up to the level of the compensation payable, ie so that the asset’s compensation would remain sufficient to replace the cash flows needed to match relevant MA eligible liabilities.
target_text: The PRA’s view is that it may be possible for firms’ criteria for assessing ‘sufficient compensation’ to be devised by reference to the relevant MA liabilities being matched by the recognised asset cash flows, together with the ability to purchase an asset of at least as good quality as the original to replace these cash flows in the event they are changed by the issuer, ie to ensure that this matching continues. The PRA expects a firm to be able to demonstrate the same level of confidence in its ability to replace cash flows as in its assessment in paragraph 2.39 above. This may, in practice, mean that the firm would recognise part of the asset’s cash flows up to the level of contractual compensation payable, subject to the considerations relating to partial recognition set out in paragraphs 2.15 to 2.16A above.

question: For compliance documentation that references the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2019/348, what identifier should be used to align the internal reference with the external Eur-Lex source, and where should the authoritative online copy be obtained?
gold_answer: When your compliance documentation cites the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2019/348, you should align the internal identifier used for the instrument with the corresponding identifier shown alongside the authoritative online source. The SOURCE establishes the instrument name as the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2019/348 and associates it with the identifier “5” [#SRC:ad9efda785802810]. The TARGET likewise presents the same identifier “5” and specifies that the text is available via an Eur-Lex PDF link, which serves as the authoritative online location for obtaining the document [#TGT:ae191aba26501494]. Accordingly, the compliant approach is to use the identifier “5” consistently when cross-referencing the instrument in internal materials, and to retrieve (and, where appropriate, cite or archive) the official version from the provided Eur-Lex URL. This ensures that the internal reference to the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2019/348 is traceable to the exact publicly available source indicated, supporting consistent cross-referencing between internal records and the external publication.
source_text: the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2019/348; 5
target_text: 5. Available at: https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/PDF/?uri=CELEX:32019R0348&rid=1 .

question: Before a credit union provides a subordinated loan, what assessment must it do, and after the loan date how long must it keep the written record of that assessment?
gold_answer: Before providing a subordinated loan, a credit union must carry out an assessment of the financial implications of making the loan; this is required to happen prior to provision, not after the fact [#TGT:070e1e95885eea3e]. Once the subordinated loan has been made, the credit union must also keep evidence that it performed that assessment by retaining a written record of it. The retention obligation is time-bound and event-triggered: the written record must be retained for five years, and the five-year period runs following the date of the subordinated loan [#SRC:33b846227c3ca9b2]. Taken together, the requirements mean the credit union needs both (1) a completed financial-implications assessment before it provides the subordinated loan and (2) a written record of that assessment that is preserved for the full five-year period after the loan date. This pairing ensures the assessment is done at the correct time and that the credit union can later demonstrate, through retained documentation, that it complied with the pre-provision assessment requirement [#TGT:070e1e95885eea3e] and the post-loan record-retention requirement [#SRC:33b846227c3ca9b2].
source_text: A credit union must retain, for a period of five years following the date of a subordinated loan, a written record of the assessment in 3.14 .
target_text: Prior to the provision of a subordinated loan, a credit union must carry out an assessment of the financial implications of making the loan.

question: For a general insurer in run-off proposing a scheme of arrangement under Part 26 of the Companies Act 2006, how should the insurer integrate its PRA Rulebook obligations (including ORSA) with the PRA’s stated approach in SS3/14, and what specific SS3/14 document identification details must be used to ensure the correct supervisory statement is being applied?
gold_answer: A general insurer in run-off proposing a scheme of arrangement under Part 26 of the Companies Act 2006 should treat its PRA Rulebook duties—specifically the Risk Management chapter in the Conditions Governing Business Part, including the requirement to carry out an Own Risk and Solvency Assessment (ORSA)—as continuing compliance obligations, while also applying the PRA’s supervisory approach set out in SS3/14, because the two supervisory statements are intended to be read together for that population. [#SRC:23f45218074bd197] To ensure the correct supervisory statement is being applied, the insurer should identify SS3/14 by its full title and publication details: “The Prudential Regulation Authority’s (PRA’s) approach to schemes of arrangement proposed by PRA-authorised insurers under Part 26 of the Companies Act 2006,” issued as PRA Supervisory Statement 3/14 in April 2014, with the referenced web location provided for that statement. [#TGT:8d6a107327860924] In practice, this means the insurer should not treat the scheme process as displacing PRA Rulebook expectations (including ORSA), but instead align scheme planning and execution with the PRA’s scheme-focused supervisory approach described in SS3/14, using the specified SS3/14 identification details to avoid applying the wrong document. [#SRC:23f45218074bd197] [#TGT:8d6a107327860924]
source_text: Insurers must comply with relevant provisions in the PRA Rulebook including the Risk Management chapter of the Conditions Governing Business Part of the PRA Rulebook, which includes requirements to undertake an Own Risk and Solvency Assessment (ORSA). This supervisory statement complements another PRA supervisory statement – SS3/14 ‘The Prudential Regulation Authority’s (PRA’s) approach to Schemes of arrangement proposed by PRA-authorised insurers under Part 26 of the Companies Act 2006’ 1 and the two should be read together for general insurers in run-off.
target_text: 1. PRA Supervisory Statement 3/14, ‘The Prudential Regulation Authority’s (PRA’s) approach to schemes of arrangement proposed by PRA-authorised insurers under Part 26 of the Companies Act 2006’, April 2014; www.bankofengland.co.uk/pra/Pages/publications/schemesss.aspx .

question: When 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies so that specified requirements must be applied “with any necessary changes” at the level of the group, how should a firm ensure its risk-management system addresses risks both individually and on an aggregated basis, and which referenced requirement set is being applied at group level to support that outcome?
gold_answer: If 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, the firm must apply the listed requirement sets “with any necessary changes” at the level of the group, meaning the firm should treat those requirements as operating on a group-wide basis rather than only on a solo-entity basis. [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552] In that group-level context, the firm’s risk-management system must be designed and maintained so it can identify, measure, monitor, manage, and report risks continuously both for each relevant unit (individual level) and across the group as a whole (aggregated level), including how risks interact with each other (interdependencies). [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca] Practically, this means the group-level application should be used to ensure the risk-management system includes strategies, processes, and reporting procedures that work across the group and can produce both entity-specific and consolidated risk views on an ongoing basis. [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca] The referenced requirement sets that are expressly to be applied at group level include, among others, Conditions Governing Business (including 2.2 to 2.6 and 2A.1 to 2A.6), Fitness and Propriety (including 2.1 to 2.3, 4.1, 4.3 and 4.4), Allocation of Responsibilities 4, and Key Function Holder – Notifications 2 to 6 (in accordance with 17.4). [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552]
source_text: (1) Where 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, the following requirements apply with any necessary changes at the level of the group : (1a) Conditions Governing Business 1A ; (a) Conditions Governing Business 2.2 to 2.6 ; (a1) Conditions Governing Business 2A.1 to 2A.6 ; (b) Conditions Governing Business 3 ; (b1) Conditions Governing Business 3A ; (c) Conditions Governing Business 4 ; (c1) Conditions Governing Business 4A ; (d) Conditions Governing Business 5 ; (e) Conditions Governing Business 6 ; (f) Conditions Governing Business 7 ; (f1) Conditions Governing Business 11A to 11F ; (g) Fitness and Propriety 2.1 to 2.3 , 4.1 , 4.3 and 4.4 ; (h) Allocation of Responsibilities 4 ; and (i) Key Function Holder – Notifications 2 to 6 , in accordance with 17.4 .
target_text: (1) A firm must establish, implement, and maintain an effective risk-management system comprising strategies, processes and reporting procedures necessary to identify, measure, monitor, manage and report on a continuous basis the risks, at an individual and at an aggregated level, to which it is or could be exposed, and their interdependencies.

question: What must a firm use to calculate the class A tariff base, and what information standard must it meet at the valuation date—especially for accounts with safeguarded funds or funds the account holder is not absolutely entitled to, and for any funds the firm has confirmed are not covered deposits?
gold_answer: A firm must calculate the Class A tariff base using covered deposits from the SCV file, and it must base that calculation on the information it would have to include in its single customer views [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1] [#TGT:cd1f61ae71a25acf]. The information used cannot be a reduced or informal dataset: it must be of the extent and standard that would be required if the firm were preparing the single customer view in accordance with the SCV requirements as at the valuation date for the tariff base [#TGT:cd1f61ae71a25acf]. When assembling the deposit balances that feed into the covered-deposit calculation, the firm must include the total balance of deposits in any account that holds funds to which the account holder is not absolutely entitled, or that are safeguarded funds, because those balances must be included under the rules for the calculation basis [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1]. At the same time, the firm may leave out funds only where it has confirmed that those funds are not covered deposits, so exclusions must be limited to confirmed non-covered amounts rather than assumptions [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1].
source_text: Depositor Protection 43 sets out the PRA’s rule for calculating the FSCS tariff base for deposit-takers (the Class A tariff base). Depositor Protection 43.2 requires firms to do this calculation on the basis of covered deposits from the SCV file. Depositor Protection 43.1 requires firms to include the total balance of deposits in any account which holds funds to which the account holder is not absolutely entitled, or which are safeguarded funds, under the rules. Any funds which the firm has confirmed are not covered deposits may be excluded.
target_text: The class A tariff base calculation must be made on the basis of the information that the firm would have to include in its single customer views . The information must be of the extent and standard required if the firm was preparing the single customer view in accordance with the SCV requirements as at the valuation date for the tariff base.

question: If a controller or proposed controller is an investment manager buying or selling listed shares as part of fund management and is following the relevant directions, what must be included with a section 178 notice to the PRA, and can the Controller’s Form be used?
gold_answer: If the controller or proposed controller is an investment manager and is buying or selling listed shares in the course of its fund management activity while complying with the specified directions, the PRA directs that it is permitted to use the Controller’s Form in that situation [#SRC:3d54441b14fbefda]. When the investment manager (or any submitter) sends a section 178 notice to the PRA in accordance with section 178(1) of FSMA, the PRA also directs that the notice must contain the information and include the documents that the approved Controller’s Form requires for the relevant application [#TGT:6dd8365d28ebc407]. Putting these together: in the listed-shares fund-management scenario described, the investment manager can use the Controller’s Form, and the notice must be completed so it includes all information the form calls for and is accompanied by all documents the form requires for that particular type of application. In other words, the form is not just optional paperwork; its required information and attachments define what the PRA expects to receive with the notice, and the investment-manager direction explains when using that form is allowed in this specific context.
source_text: Where a controller or proposed controller that is an investment manager is complying with the directions in 2.1 and 2.3 in connection with the acquiring or disposal of listed shares in the course its fund management activity, the PRA directs that it may use the Controller’s form at 6.5 .
target_text: The PRA directs that a section 178 notice submitted to the PRA in accordance with section 178(1) of FSMA must contain the information and be accompanied by such documents as are required by the Controller’s Form approved for the relevant application.

question: How should a firm populate and structure the single customer view and exclusions view when certain data items in the required information set are not held by the firm or are not applicable, given the obligation that each view must contain all information set out in the table?
gold_answer: A firm should build each single customer view (SCV) and exclusions view so that it includes the full set of fields corresponding to the required information, while leaving particular fields blank only where the firm does not hold the data or the data item does not apply. [#TGT:ad978d8ce164b1e0] Where data required for inclusion are not held or are not applicable, the firm should keep the relevant fields present in the SCV and exclusions view file but leave those fields empty, so the files remain standard in length. [#SRC:697a55e1d316e0fa] The firm should also maintain a consistent field sequence: fields should always appear in the same order as set out in Depositor Protection 12.9, even when some fields are empty. [#SRC:697a55e1d316e0fa] At the same time, the firm must complete all fields that are mandatory, and must also complete fields where the data are applicable and held by the firm; completion of all fields is mandatory unless the field is indicated as not applicable or not held (where not mandatory). [#SRC:697a55e1d316e0fa] In practice, this means the firm satisfies the requirement that each SCV and exclusions view contains all the information set out in the table by ensuring every required field exists in the file structure, while using empty values only for permitted “not held/not applicable” cases and fully populating mandatory and applicable-held data items. [#TGT:ad978d8ce164b1e0] [#SRC:697a55e1d316e0fa]
source_text: Where firms do not hold the data required to be included in the SCV or exclusions view file or the data are not applicable, corresponding fields in the SCV and exclusions view file should remain empty. Even if these fields are empty, the PRA expects these fields to remain in the SCV file and the exclusions view file, so that the files are standard in length. Fields should always appear in the same order set out in Depositor Protection 12.9 . Completion of all fields is mandatory unless otherwise indicated (ie not applicable or not held by the firm (where not mandatory)). Firms must complete all fields where data are mandatory, or where applicable and held by the firm.
target_text: A firm must ensure that each single customer view and exclusions view contains all the information set out in the table below.

question: When a derivative transaction presents more than one material risk driver, how shall institutions determine whether to map it to a single risk category or to multiple risk categories, and how does that obligation interact with the requirement to base mapping on the transaction’s primary risk driver as the only material risk driver?
gold_answer: Institutions must apply two linked requirements. Under the TARGET obligation, institutions must conduct mapping on the basis of the primary risk driver of a derivative transaction, and that primary risk driver is defined as the only material risk driver of the transaction [#TGT:7c541aa6ba03b9a1]. In parallel, the SOURCE sets out how institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver: they must map to more than one risk category, unless all material risk drivers fall within the same risk category, in which case the transaction is mapped only once to that category based on the most material risk driver; if the material risk drivers span different risk categories, the transaction is mapped once to each relevant risk category based on the most material risk driver within each category [#SRC:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. Read together, institutions should first identify whether the transaction is treated as having a single material risk driver (the primary risk driver) for mapping purposes under the TARGET, and where the SOURCE scenario of multiple material risk drivers applies, they must follow the SOURCE’s single- versus multi-category mapping logic and the “most material” basis within the applicable category or categories.
source_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.
target_text: Institutions shall conduct the mapping referred to in paragraph 1 on the basis of the primary risk driver of a derivative transaction. The primary risk driver shall be the only material risk driver of a derivative transaction.

question: When preparing disclosures on compliance with the capital requirements framework, what must Institutions publish, and how must they structure the disclosures so that the information required for their compliance statement is also delivered in the prescribed table-and-instructions format?
gold_answer: Institutions have a dual disclosure obligation that must be met in a coordinated way. First, they must disclose specified information about their compliance with the applicable capital requirements framework, i.e., information regarding their compliance with Article 92 and the referenced Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment requirements in the PRA Rulebook [#TGT:8982dfdcaf17bcb9]. Second, they must also make the disclosures required under the CRR disclosure regime for the relevant items, and they must do so using the prescribed presentation and completion approach—specifically, in accordance with Table UK OVC in Annex I and the relevant instructions set out in Annex II [#SRC:519a769e69cbab70]. Read together, this means Institutions should ensure that the compliance-related information they are required to disclose is produced and presented in a manner that satisfies both regimes: the content obligation to disclose information about compliance, and the format/process obligation to make the required CRR disclosures using the mandated table and accompanying instructions. The disclosures should therefore be prepared so that the required compliance information is captured and communicated through the required table-based structure and instruction set.
source_text: Institutions shall make the disclosures required in points (a) and (c) of Article 438 of the CRR in accordance with the Table UK OVC in Annex I and the relevant instructions set out in Annex II .
target_text: Institutions shall disclose the following information regarding their compliance with Article 92 and rules 3.1(1)(a) and 3.4 of the Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment Part of the PRA Rulebook :

question: When planning for continuity of critical services during potential changes to service provision arising from restructuring related to recovery or resolution, may firms draw on their implementation of the Bank of England Statement of Policy on Restructuring Planning, and if so what capability must firms still maintain across scenarios?
gold_answer: Firms may draw on their implementation of the Bank of England Statement of Policy ‘Restructuring Planning’ as a resource when developing their approach to continuity planning in the context of restructuring related to recovery or resolution [#TGT:2adfa31e81fef236]. However, using that external policy as an input does not displace the expectation that, in implementing the relevant operational continuity requirement, firms should have the capability to ensure continuity of critical services during possible changes to service provision resulting from such restructuring [#SRC:59c21b8c65ce33a6]. In practice, this means the firm’s continuity capability must be designed to operate irrespective of the scenarios the firm may encounter during the restructuring, rather than being limited to a single assumed pathway or outcome [#SRC:59c21b8c65ce33a6]. Firms should therefore take different scenarios into account in planning for continuity, so that continuity arrangements remain effective even as service provision changes during restructuring, while still being able to leverage relevant elements of their implementation of the Bank of England policy to inform that planning [#TGT:2adfa31e81fef236] [#SRC:59c21b8c65ce33a6].
source_text: In implementing Operational Continuity 3.1(2), firms should have the capability to ensure continuity of critical services during possible changes to service provision resulting from restructuring related to recovery or resolution. 16 Firms should have the capability to ensure continuity irrespective of the scenarios that they may encounter during such a restructuring and should take different scenarios into account in planning for continuity.
target_text: 16. Firms may be able to draw on their implementation of the Bank of England Statement of Policy ‘Restructuring Planning’, available at: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/financial-stability/resolution/resolvability-assessment-framework/resolvability-assessment-framework-policy-documents .

question: When institutions are determining exposure values for transactions under a contractual netting agreement, what is the required calculation sequence for using a single exposure value versus separate exposure values, and in that process when may two perfectly matching OTC derivative contracts in the same netting agreement be treated as one contract with a zero notional principal?
gold_answer: Institutions should first determine whether the transactions fall within a contractual netting agreement for which the applicable conditions are met; if so, they may calculate a single exposure value covering all transactions within that agreement, and if not, they must calculate an exposure value separately for each transaction, treating each as its own netting set [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c]. Within the scenario where institutions are calculating exposure value in accordance with the relevant methods, they are permitted to simplify the treatment of two OTC derivative contracts that are included in the same netting agreement and are perfectly matching by treating them as if they were a single contract with a notional principal equal to zero [#SRC:14f4743e51835715]. Practically, this means the procedural decision point is whether the contractual netting agreement qualifies for a single exposure value; once that approach is available, the institution can apply the permitted contract-level treatment for perfectly matching OTC derivative contracts inside the same netting agreement as part of its exposure value calculation methodology, while otherwise defaulting to transaction-by-transaction exposure values and separate netting sets as required [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c] and permitted [#SRC:14f4743e51835715].
source_text: In calculating the exposure value in accordance with the methods set out in Sections 3 , 4 and 5 , institutions may treat two OTC derivative contracts included in the same netting agreement that are perfectly matching as if they were a single contract with a notional principal equal to zero.
target_text: Institutions may calculate a single exposure value for all the transactions within a contractual netting agreement where all the conditions set out in Article 274(1) are met. Otherwise, institutions shall calculate an exposure value separately for each transaction, which shall be treated as its own netting set.

question: When adjusting the value ascribed to assets under 18 to 19, in what circumstances must a firm treat assets as being deemed acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option, and how does that deemed treatment affect the increase or decrease applied for assets of the relevant description?
gold_answer: A firm must adjust the value ascribed under 18 to 19 for each asset description by adding or subtracting the value of assets of that description that the firm is treated as having acquired or disposed of under an option. [#TGT:edaf68ec91a76124] For the purposes of 20.1, that deemed acquisition or disposal arises only where, at the relevant date, the firm is a party to an option and it is prudent to assume the option will be exercised, and the option is of the type described in the rule. [#SRC:bd531cb4e2558157] In practice, this means the firm first identifies whether, at the relevant date, it meets the option-party and prudent-assumption conditions that trigger deemed acquisition/disposal under 20.1. [#SRC:bd531cb4e2558157] If those conditions are met, the firm must then reflect the resulting deemed position directly in the 18 to 19 valuation by increasing or decreasing the value ascribed for the corresponding asset description by the value of the assets deemed acquired or disposed of. [#TGT:edaf68ec91a76124] The direction of the adjustment (increase versus decrease) follows whether the firm is deemed to have acquired or to have disposed of assets pursuant to the option. [#TGT:edaf68ec91a76124]
source_text: For the purposes of 20.1 , the firm must be deemed to have acquired or disposed of assets pursuant to an option if, at the relevant date , it is a party to an option and it is prudent to assume that the option will be exercised and the option is one which:
target_text: The value ascribed under 18 to 19 in respect of assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description which the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option .

question: If a firm uses its own internal credit assessments, what does the PRA expect the firm to validate about its method (including credit risk sources), and what checks must the results pass against CRA-style ratings (plausible range and no bias) so the PRA can be comfortable with the basic FS?
gold_answer: The PRA expects a firm to validate both how its internal credit assessment is built and what it produces, so the PRA can gain assurance about the appropriateness of the basic FS. [#TGT:5fd5739308652721] On the “how,” the firm should validate its internal credit assessment methodology and criteria, including how it has identified and allowed for all sources of credit risk, using qualitative and/or quantitative approaches. [#SRC:4f0228446ac0d767] On the “what,” the internal credit assessment outcomes must sit within the plausible range of issue ratings that could have been produced by a CRA, and they must be broadly consistent and not biased versus CRA issue ratings when viewed at the asset type level and across the portfolio. [#TGT:5fd5739308652721] The PRA also expects the firm’s validation work to ensure the outcomes satisfy the points referenced in paragraph 2.4, meaning the validation should explicitly confirm the outcomes meet those stated expectations rather than stopping at methodology review. [#SRC:4f0228446ac0d767] Using sample assets assessed by a CRA can help show broad consistency, but the firm should not rely on credit ratings alone or in a purely mechanical way when judging creditworthiness. [#TGT:5fd5739308652721]
source_text: The PRA expects that, as part of the requirement for a firm to have an internal credit assessment process that is subject to appropriate validation as per Matching Adjustment 7.2(4) , the firm will have validated its internal credit assessment methodology and criteria, including how it has identified and allowed for all sources of credit risk, whether qualitatively or quantitatively. In addition, the PRA expects the firm’s validation to ensure that the internal credit assessment outcomes have satisfied the points in paragraph 2.4 above.
target_text: [First sentence moved to 2.4B ] As part of demonstrating that internal credit assessments are of a comparable standard to a credit rating as per Matching Adjustment 7.1(1) , Matching Adjustment 7.2(2) requires that internal credit assessment outcomes lie within the plausible range of issue ratings that could have resulted from a CRA. Matching Adjustment 7.2(3) also requires broad consistency and no bias within the plausible range between firms’ internal credit assessment outcomes and CRA issue ratings at an asset type and the portfolio level. These requirements will help to give the PRA some assurance that the basic FS is appropriate. Having sample assets assessed by a CRA will additionally help demonstrate broad consistency between a firm’s internal credit assessment outcomes and comparable CRA issue ratings. Nevertheless, firms should not solely or mechanistically rely on credit ratings for assessing the creditworthiness of an entity or financial instrument. 12

question: When forming the opinion required by Rules 2.1 and 4.1 of the External Audit Part of the PRA Rulebook, what is the auditor’s responsibility regarding (i) assessing whether a firm meets the eligibility conditions for use of the MA and (ii) opining on the validity of approvals, waivers, or other supervisory determinations, and how should those determinations be treated in the audit framework (including in the context of transitional measures on technical provisions)?
gold_answer: In forming the opinion required by Rules 2.1 and 4.1 of the External Audit Part of the PRA Rulebook, the auditor does not have to test whether the firm satisfies the eligibility conditions for use of the MA, and the auditor is also not expected to validate the correctness of any approval, waiver, or other supervisory determination. [#SRC:7bd251a3e64bccff] Instead, approvals, waivers, and supervisory determinations issued by the competent authority are inputs to the basis on which the audit opinion is formed, rather than matters the auditor re-adjudicates. [#TGT:15d29d4311dd73f6] This means the auditor’s work is framed around applying the audit opinion to the relevant reporting framework while accepting those supervisory outcomes as given. [#TGT:15d29d4311dd73f6] For transitional measures on technical provisions specifically, the framework the auditor uses should also incorporate Pillar 1 and 2 assets, liabilities, and capital that are calculated under the previous regime, treating those amounts as part of the same framework against which the audit opinion is provided. [#TGT:15d29d4311dd73f6] Taken together, the auditor’s role is to deliver the required Rules 2.1 and 4.1 opinion without reassessing MA eligibility or second-guessing supervisory decisions, while still reflecting those decisions (and relevant transitional-measure elements) in the framework used for the opinion. [#SRC:7bd251a3e64bccff] [#TGT:15d29d4311dd73f6]
source_text: In forming the opinion required by Rules 2.1 and 4.1 of the External Audit Part of the PRA Rulebook, auditors are not required to assess whether a firm meets the eligibility conditions for use of the MA. As noted in paragraph 3.4 , auditors are not expected to express an opinion on the validity of an approval, waiver or other supervisory determination.
target_text: The auditor is not expected to express an opinion on the validity of an approval, waiver or other supervisory determination. Instead approvals, waivers and supervisory determinations provided by the competent authority should be considered as part of the framework against which the audit opinion is being given. For the purposes of transitional measures on technical provisions, Pillar 1 and 2 assets, liabilities and capital calculated in accordance with the previous regime, should be treated as part of the framework against which the audit opinion is being given.

question: If a firm is working out the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business, what should it do when it has at least one past financial year to look at, and what amount applies if it is too new to have a preceding financial year?
gold_answer: The firm should start by checking whether it has a preceding financial year, because that determines whether it uses an income-based table or a fixed amount. [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993] If the firm does have one or more preceding financial years, it must look back across those years and find its highest annual contribution income for long-term insurance business, then match that highest income level to the table so it can take the minimum guarantee fund amount shown for that income band. [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993] If the firm is too new to have a preceding financial year, it cannot apply the table method that depends on identifying the highest annual contribution income in a preceding year; in that case, the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is set at £90,000. [#TGT:57922715d15fab69] This means the same firm could have different minimum guarantee fund outcomes depending on whether it has historical annual contribution income data from a preceding financial year (table-based) or lacks that history (the £90,000 default). [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993] [#TGT:57922715d15fab69]
source_text: Subject to 6.2 , the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is the amount in column 2 of the following table, which corresponds to the firm’s highest annual contribution income in respect of that business in any preceding financial year , as shown in column 1 of the table:
target_text: If a firm has not been in existence long enough to have a preceding financial year , the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is £90,000.

question: If a firm has been told by its supervisor that it qualifies for Simplified Obligations, what does it still need to do about recovery plan scenarios, and what parts of recovery planning are reduced for that firm?
gold_answer: Simplified Obligations apply only to firms that the PRA applies them to and that have been notified by their supervisor that they meet the eligibility criteria; for those firms, the reduced recovery planning obligations apply in respect of scenarios and the information template [#SRC:1714a0d1f587bfcb]. Even so, the PRA expects firms to follow the EBA ‘Guidelines on the range of scenarios to be used in recovery plans’ alongside the expectations in the supervisory statement [#TGT:9394388668fe0fa9]. That means an eligible firm should still include at least two scenarios from the EBA guidelines that are sufficiently severe to test the recovery plan and are most relevant to the firm’s business model [#TGT:9394388668fe0fa9]. In line with the EBA guidelines, the firm should also include a scenario that combines system-wide and idiosyncratic events, and the PRA expects firms (including those eligible for Simplified Obligations) to include this combined scenario because it is the most challenging and requires considering trade-offs between capital and liquidity impacts from recovery options when developing the recovery strategy [#TGT:9394388668fe0fa9].
source_text: The PRA applies Simplified Obligations for recovery planning (Simplified Obligations) to firms that have been notified by their supervisor that they meet the eligibility criteria. For these firms, the reduced recovery planning obligations apply in respect of scenarios and the information template (paragraphs 2.54 – 2.55 and 2.70 ). Additional information in relation to the approach that smaller and less complex firms should take in respect of certain aspects of recovery planning is included where relevant in this SS.
target_text: The EBA has published ‘Guidelines on the range of scenarios to be used in recovery plans’. The PRA expects firms to follow these guidelines alongside the expectations set out in this SS. Firms that are eligible for Simplified Obligations should include at least two of the scenarios set out in the EBA guidelines that are sufficiently severe to test the recovery plan and are most relevant to the firm’s business model. In accordance with the EBA guidelines, firms should include a scenario with a combination of system-wide and idiosyncratic events. The PRA therefore expects firms, including those eligible for Simplified Obligations, to include a combined system-wide and idiosyncratic event, as these scenarios are the most challenging, as firms need to consider potential trade-offs between capital and liquidity impacts from recovery options when developing a recovery strategy.

question: When allocating responsibilities within a firm’s senior management arrangements, how should the firm treat a person who performs an FCA designated senior management function (noting the “subject to 3.6(1)” qualifier) in light of the prohibition on allocating a prescribed responsibility to a person who performs an FCA other overall responsibility senior management function?
gold_answer: A firm must treat the prohibition as applying specifically to individuals who perform an “FCA other overall responsibility senior management function,” and it must not allocate a prescribed responsibility to such a person. [#TGT:afb87828d72640b4] Separately, the population of individuals who may be relevant to the firm’s senior management arrangements includes those who perform a PRA senior management function and those who perform an FCA designated senior management function, with the latter category expressly framed as being “subject to 3.6(1).” [#SRC:3a4602dcc6094903] In practice, this means the firm should first identify whether the individual in question is within the senior management function categories described (PRA senior management function or FCA designated senior management function, as qualified). [#SRC:3a4602dcc6094903] If the individual also performs an FCA other overall responsibility senior management function, the firm is prohibited from allocating any prescribed responsibility to that individual, regardless of their status as a PRA senior management function holder or FCA designated senior management function holder. [#TGT:afb87828d72640b4] The “subject to 3.6(1)” wording signals that the FCA designated senior management function category is not unconditional, so the firm should apply that qualifier when determining whether the person is treated as performing that function for these purposes. [#SRC:3a4602dcc6094903]
source_text: (1) performs a PRA senior management function or, subject to 3.6 (1), an FCA designated senior management function ; and
target_text: (1) A firm must not allocate a prescribed responsibility to a person who performs an FCA other overall responsibility senior management function .

question: Before the Merger Notification Statement is issued to members, what must occur in relation to PRA approval, and how must the board address interim material changes to the society’s financial position given that the financial information may be out of date by the approval date?
gold_answer: Before the Merger Notification Statement is sent to the members, it must already have been approved by the PRA, and it must then be sent within the specified time limit [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc]. In parallel, because the financial information included in the Schedule 16 Statement will relate to a period ending before the date that statement is approved, the board must explicitly state whether there have been any material changes to the financial position in the interim [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. Where a change has been identified but cannot be quantified, the board must still describe the effect so that members understand it is relevant to their consideration of the proposed merger [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. These requirements work together to ensure that, at the point the PRA-approved member communication is issued, members are not relying on stale financial information without an accompanying statement about intervening developments. The target text also makes clear that failure to disclose such interim changes will be relevant to the PRA’s later consideration of the society’s application for confirmation of the merger [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1], reinforcing the importance of accurate, up-to-date disclosure alongside the PRA approval and timely dispatch obligations [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc].
source_text: The Merger Notification Statement must have been approved by the PRA before it is sent to the members, and must be sent within the specified time limit. Applications for approval should, in general, follow the procedure described in paragraph 3.73 , and the final draft of the Merger Notification Statement should be accompanied by the relevant documents listed in paragraph 3.98 , but as appropriate to the particular case and the less extensive information the statement is required to contain. The statement must include particulars of any compensation payable to directors or other officers of the transferor society to which the PRA has given its consent under paragraph 2(1) of Schedule 8A to the 1986 Act.
target_text: Since the financial information will necessarily relate to a period ending somewhat before the date of approval of the Schedule 16 Statement, the board is required to state whether or not there have been any material changes to the financial position in the interim. If the effect of a change cannot be quantified, it must be described so that the members at least know that it has been identified and is relevant to their consideration of the proposed merger. Failure to disclose such changes will be relevant to the PRA’s subsequent consideration of the society’s application for confirmation of the merger (see paragraphs 3.157 , 3.169 and 3.170 ).

question: In an amalgamation where a society is preparing its formal application to the PRA (including approval of a Schedule 16 Statement), what early-stage draft clearances are expected with the FCA and PRA, and what specific signed documents and number of copies must be sent when applying to the PRA for confirmation under Section 93(2) of the 1986 Act?
gold_answer: For an amalgamation, the societies should treat the formal PRA application (including approval of a Schedule 16 Statement) as the endpoint of an iterative process in which PRA staff have reviewed drafts of the Statement alongside drafts of the Instrument of Transfer (or amalgamation agreement) and related prudential information, and the societies should also have cleared the proposed Memorandum and Rules of the successor society with both the FCA and the PRA. [#TGT:b82c2ae32466a535] In parallel, because the FCA must be satisfied about the proposed Rules, Memorandum, and the successor society’s name, the amalgamating societies are advised to clear drafts of the proposed Rules and Memorandum with the FCA at an early stage. [#SRC:4c98e92939aed724] When the societies apply to the PRA for confirmation under Section 93(2) of the 1986 Act, they must send three signed copies of the Rules and Memorandum to both the PRA and the FCA. [#SRC:4c98e92939aed724] This sequencing links the early draft-clearance expectation (with FCA and PRA) to the later, formal submission requirement (three signed copies to each regulator) as part of progressing the amalgamation through PRA confirmation and related regulatory review. [#TGT:b82c2ae32466a535] [#SRC:4c98e92939aed724]
source_text: In the case of an amalgamation, the FCA is required to be satisfied as regards the proposed Rules, Memorandum and name of the successor society. The amalgamating societies are, therefore, advised to clear drafts of the proposed Rules and Memorandum with the FCA at an early stage (see paragraph 3.96 ). When they apply to the PRA for confirmation under Section 93(2) of the 1986 Act, the amalgamating societies must send three signed copies of the Rules and Memorandum to the PRA and the FCA (Section 93(2)(d)). If the FCA is satisfied on these matters it will, upon confirmation by the PRA , register the successor society and issue to it a certificate of incorporation specifying the date (the specified date) from which the incorporation takes effect, and will return to it one copy each of the Rules and Memorandum together with a certificate of registration. Copies are placed on the public file of the successor society.
target_text: A society’s formal application to the PRA for approval of a Schedule 16 Statement is likely to be the culmination of many weeks of discussion with the PRA’s staff who will have reviewed and commented upon a draft or successive drafts of the Statement, having had regard also to drafts of the Instrument of Transfer (or amalgamation agreement) and the prudential information described in ‘Preliminary matters’ . Societies should also have cleared any proposed Rule changes or, in the case of an amalgamation, the proposed Memorandum and Rules of the successor society, with the FCA and the PRA.

question: If a related Solvency II undertaking included in group solvency has placed an own funds item in Tier 2 under the tiering criteria, what is the group’s obligation regarding same-tier classification, and what permission applies where the item would qualify for Tier 1 and group-level limits are satisfied?
gold_answer: The group must generally follow the tier assigned by the related Solvency II undertaking: where the undertaking included in the calculation of the group solvency has classified an own funds item into one of the three tiers based on the tiering criteria, the item is required to be classified in the same tier at group level, provided the additional requirements for that approach are met [#TGT:669a47dbe318f67a]. In parallel, there is an express permission that addresses the situation where the undertaking’s Tier 2 treatment would otherwise constrain the group: notwithstanding the undertaking’s inclusion of the item in Tier 2, if that own funds item would qualify for inclusion in Tier 1, the undertaking-level Tier 2 classification does not prohibit the group from classifying the same item in Tier 1 at group level, so long as the applicable group-level limits are complied with [#SRC:d7efe71fb905e0c9]. Accordingly, the compliance analysis must consider both (i) whether the conditions for same-tier classification at group level are met and (ii) whether the specific conditions for the permitted Tier 1 classification at group level are satisfied despite the undertaking’s Tier 2 classification.
source_text: Notwithstanding 8A.1 , where a related Solvency II undertaking has included in Tier 2 own funds an own funds item which would qualify for inclusion in Tier 1 own funds in accordance with Own Funds 3E.1(11) , that classification shall not prohibit the classification of the same own funds item in Tier 1 own funds at group level, provided that the limits set out in Own Funds 4A.3 are complied with at group level.
